DOC.HEAD: A Story of Thanksgiving: The Needy Glean Food from Harvested Fields
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY307 Nov. 15.
DOC.TEXT: The harvest has been abundant this year - fat tomatoes, sweet potatoes, melons, pecans and purple-hull peas. The rains came, as farmers gathered in a spring field prayed they would. ``We were blessed,'' produce grower Louis Lazzari said. At Thanksgiving dinner in Annie White's house, the grace her ill 80-year-old husband Jack plans to say will be simple: ``He'll say he hopes it continues.'' By that, she meant not just the fecundity of the good earth here by Mobile Bay, but the sharing of its riches between farmers like Lazzari and families like hers, families in need, through people known as ``gleaners.'' From bean-growing time in the spring to the gathering of mustard greens, turnips and broccoli in cool weather, farmers invite the gleaners into their fields to take what's left behind after harvest. On one afternoon this summer, 200 hands picked 16,220 pounds of tomatoes. Altogether last year, the gleaners, organized by a local group called Ecumenical Ministries, carried away 100,000 pounds of vegetables and fruits. The pickers must be needy. They cannot sell anything they glean. And they must share it with someone else in need - such as the Whites, who cannot pick on their ownbecause they're disabled. The rules are as simple as the verses from the Old Testament that underlie the 10-year-old project. ``When thou cuttest down thine harvest ... and hast forgotten a sheaf in the field, thou shalt not go again to fetch it,'' enjoins Deuteronomy 24:19-21. ``It shall be for the stranger, for the fatherless, and for the widow. That the Lord thy God may bless thee in all the work of thine hands.'' Mrs. White, who at 69 has heart trouble and more other ailments than she can name, and whose husband has cancer, learned of Ecumenical Ministries about eight years ago, on a day she was desperate for food. ``That day, I really didn't have anything to cook,'' she said. ``Before I looked around, it was no time before they were out with boxes and bags of groceries,'' she said. After that, gleaners brought regular deliveries of whatever vegetable was in season. Without the food, she said, ``I guess I'd starve.'' The program began a decade ago with Dot Threadgill, who saw a television news item about people from a California senior citizens center who supplemented their diet by picking leftovers in the fields. Mrs. Threadgill's energy seems to keep the gleaning operations going - and growing, from about 300 pounds of food distributed during the first year, ``about half of that out of my garden,'' she said. Now, 15 farmers call her or she calls them as harvests near. And she's learned tricks over the years. ``Mechanical harvesters can't pick where they turn, at the end of the rows,'' she said, referring to potato picking machines. ``So we know where to be.'' She scouts the fields, estimating how many gleaners the crop will feed plentifully - ``We don't want them to use their gas money and not have sufficient for several days.'' Then she quickly goes to the ``telephone tree'' to mobilize pickers before the farmer plows the field under to prepare for the next crop. Suzanne Zellner got a call when a turnip patch was offered recently. She and her husband have five children, the youngest 2{-year-old twins. Besides improving nutrition and stretching grocery money, gleaning has an educational value, she said, teaching children ``how to pick, how to know when something's ready or when it's too ripe.'' Another regular in the fields is Gussie Winston, 53, who first went gleaning because her family had nothing to eat, but now makes ends meet with housekeeping jobs and gleans and cans vegetables for herself and a list of mostly elderly people unable to get out themselves. ``When you become a gleaner, you're an emissary,'' she said, looking across a sunny field to pickers stooped at their work. ``You're supposed to see that no one goes hungry.'' For Mrs. Threadgill, that requires judicious juggling of her phone list. For instance, she said, ``I know that Mary Jones has 10 or 15 people under her; so I know that if there's only enough for 10 or 15 I don't need to call but Mary ... ``And if we get peas for Mary this week, we call somebody else, and kind of divide around the wealth.'' And the wealth keeps blooming. Around the Fourth of July, one farmer makes sure to call the gleaners to gather ripe watermelons. Just before Christmas last year, a rare spell of extreme cold brought a call from another farmer who said he couldn't protect all of his broccoli crop. The gleaners cut 1,200 pounds. A grower who has a U-pick operation, with tomatoes planted in a staggered schedule, offers the gleaners what's left in ``dead-ripe patches'' that his paying customers picked through the week before. Standing in the shade of an old pecan tree on his farm, 60-year-old Louis Lazzari said the vagariesof the market sometimes open his fields to the gleaners. ``This year, one day I sold my broker 240 bushel boxes of beans and he wanted the next day 340,'' he said. ``I had the beans, some of the prettiest I ever raised in my life.'' But the going price wouldn't have covered expenses. ``After I paid the help, I paid for the box, I paid the freight to the place of business, I don't know honestly but I may have went backwards. ``I could have plowed 'em under,'' Lazzari said. But really he couldn't. ``It hurts me so bad to see something ... go to waste,'' he said. And he knows there are plenty of people here who haven't had his good fortune. ``I was born in the Depression,'' he said, ``but I never had to go to bed one day in my life without a decent meal, I'm thankful to say.'' Instead of plowing those pretty beans under, he phoned Mrs. Threadgill. Once, a few years ago, Lazzari spontaneously called and offered sweet corn, 30 big croker sacks full. Mrs. Threadgill went back a few days later to thank him with a cake. ``He said, `You know, I had that big field of corn, and it wasn't moving. After I gave you that 30 sacks, that evening a man came and bought the whole field from me.' '' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Christopher Sullivan is the AP's Southeast regional reporter, based in Atlanta.

Controversial Theologian, Denied Tenure, Now Focus Of Academic Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: An academic dispute with roots in the Vatican is growing at Auburn University, a state school known more for producing farmers and football players than Roman Catholic rifts. The controversy centers on the Rev. Charles E. Curran, who was selected for an endowed professorship at Auburn although he is the only American barred by Rome from teaching Catholic theology. His views on topics such as abortion and contraception have put him at odds with the Vatican for years. But it was Curran's treatment by Auburn President James Martin that has enraged the university senate, a faculty-staff body. Martin denied tenure for Curran, although the post was advertised as being a tenured - or permanent - position, and hasn't explained his decision publicly or to Curran. He denies the conclusion of a senate committee that he violated university tenure policies. ``Thus far he's the most controversial person we have ever hired,'' Martin said in an interview Thursday. The senate scheduled a special meeting for Tuesday to discuss Curran's treatment, and chairman Gary Mullen said the senate is likely to take some kind of formal stance against Martin. ``The action could range from doing nothing, which is not expected at all, to requesting tenure ... to a formal censure of the president,'' Mullen said. A blowup over religious beliefs and academic freedom is uncharacteristic at Auburn, a land-grant school in a mostly Protestant state with 21,000 students and a reputation for achievement in agriculture and athletics. Last year, its religion department had only two full-time teachers and a pair of graduates. But academic eruptions are not completely foreign to Auburn in east-central Alabama. The school was censured in 1983 by the American Association of University Professors following another tenure dispute, and the rebuke has not been lifted. Curran, author of 20 books on Christian ethics and morality, lost his last tenured position - at Catholic University in Washington - in 1986. The Vatican said his dissenting views on conservative church positions made him unfit to teach theology. Among other things, he supports abortion in limited circumstances. Since then, Curran has held temporary posts at Cornell University and the University of Southern California, where he was working when Auburn called. While Curran's views earned a Vatican rebuff, they have not cut him off from the rest of the church. Some 750 Catholic theologians have signed a statement backing him, and the University of Notre Dame continues to publish his books. He has been president of three major theological societies. ``He's considered quite moderate, actually. He's fairly conservative,'' said John Ehmann, administrative director of Notre Dame Press. ``Only a right-wing fanatic would refer to Charlie Curran as a way-out theologian,'' said the Rev. Richard McBrien, head of theology at Notre Dame. ``The Vatican is way out. He's a centrist.'' ``A tiny minority of Catholics in Alabama has influenced an academic decision at a major state institution,'' said McBrien. Curran said his views represent those of the Catholic mainstream. McBrien said Curran has been a target for Rome since 1968, when he led opposition to a Vatican decree against artificial birth control. Curran's post is a new endowed chair created through a program approved by the Alabama Legislature. The ``eminent scholars'' plan is supposed to boost the reputations of state-supported schools by attracting leading academicians. The university advertised the chair nationwide as being a tenured position -meaning it was a lifetime job except for severe misconduct. Curran said it was with that understanding that he decided to take the job, after he was recommended by a search committee and discussed it with a school vice president. ``I wouldn't have gotten near the thing if I didn't think it was tenured,'' Curran, 56, said last week. But Curran said that once he had called Auburn to formally accept the chair, he was told Martin had decided against tenure. Curran said he had little choice but to come to Auburn for this school year, having turned down other job offers in favor of the Auburn post. Martin and Auburn's trustees have denied that any outside pressure led to the decision. The sole Catholic on Auburn's board, Bessie Mae Holloway, has denied any involvement in the tenure decision. But Curran said Catholic Archbishop Oscar Lipscomb of Mobile told him of twice talking with Mrs. Holloway, although Lipscomb denies being against Curran's hiring. The episode has been a disappointment for Curran, who had hoped to put his disputes with Rome behind him. ``One of my reasons for even thinking of Auburn is it would be a quiet place where I could fade into the woodwork and do my work,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Donated Hair to War Effort - Used For Cross Hairs In Bombsight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When Americans everywhere were giving up luxuries for the effort to win World War II, Mary Babnick Brown gave up something much more personal than a favorite food - her below-knee-length hair. Brown, now 83, was honored Saturday for contributing to the war effort. In a ceremony at the U.S. Air Force Academy, she received a special achievement award from the Colorado Aviation Historical Society. What she didn't know back in 1942 was that her hair was used as cross hairs in a secret bombsight used on bombers. Brown said she didn't really want to give up her blond hair, but caring for it was becoming a lot of work. The government wanted hair at least 22 inches long. She sent 34 inches - hair that had only been trimmed, never really cut, for her first 36 years. In 1942, she saw an advertisement in a Pueblo newspaper that the government was looking for women to contribute their hair to the war effort, she sent an inquiry and quickly received a telegram asking her to send a sample. A few days later, she received another telegram pleading for her hair. It was exactly what they needed, said officials with the Institute of Technology in Washington, D.C. ``I saw so many people crying their eyes out, not wanting their sons to go,'' she said. ``I was sad. I wanted to do something for the war effort.'' Bill Feder, founder of the International B-24 Memorial Museum in Pueblo, learned recently that a Pueblo woman had donated her hair, and he began looking for her. He told Brown that her hair was used experimentally as cross hairs in a bomb-aiming device known as the Norden bombsight. The bombsight, invented in the mid-1930s by a Swiss immigrant named Karl Norden, was essentially a mechanical computer used in high altitude bombing. The device took into account such things as altitude, the plane's speed and wind velocity. When the target reached the center of the cross hairs, the crew could drop the bomb with dependable accuracy. Used on the B-24 Liberator, the B-29 Super Fortress and the B-17 Flying Fortress, the Norden bombsight was so secret that it was equipped with explosives, Feder said, and crews were ordered to destroy it if their bomber ran the risk of falling into enemy hands. At altitudes as high as 20,000 feet, the bombsight cross hairs were subjected to freezing temperatures and rapid changes in humidity. Black widow spider webs, which contracted and expanded on scale under those conditions, were originally used but were fragile and hard to come by. Feder said Brown's fine blonde hair, which had never been bleached or touched with a hot iron, was unique and shared many of the qualities valued in the black widow spider's web. In addition to the bombsight, her hair was used in scientific equipment such as humidity measuring devices important in the production of airplanes and other war machinery. The Norden bombsight eventually was replaced by electronic bombsights, but when the newer devices did not prove accurate enough to drop radio transmitters along jungle trails in Vietnam, the Norden bombsight was successfully used to do the job.

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Erupts After Nearly 200 Years Dormant
DOC.TEXT: Steam and hot mud spewed Sunday from a volcano that was dormant since causing one of Japan's largest natural disasters nearly 200 years ago. No injuries have been reported since Mount Unzen erupted Saturday, and no evacuations were reported. The volcano is about 510 miles southwest of Tokyo on the island of Kyushu. The eruption also did not appear to worry tourists visiting hot springs near the crater. The town of Unzen, about 2{ miles from the volcano, currently has about 3,000 tourists, said Unzen Tourist Association spokesman Tadakiyo Kato. ``All the rooms at Unzen hotels are full,'' Kato said. ``We have been booked solid because of the autumn tourist season, and no one has canceled out because of the eruption.'' The 4,458-foot volcano, composed of several volcanic peaks, last erupted in 1792, killing 15,000 people in the worst volcano-related disaster in Japanese history. Many of the deaths were caused by a huge landslide and tidal waves. Scientists and local police refused to make predictions on the eruption, but said they were preparing for the worst. Lava flows are not expected, but ``it is impossible to tell for certain,'' said an official at the Mount Unzen Observatory, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Twin plumes of steam and ash rose hundreds of yards into the air. Observatory seismographs recorded temblors too weak to be felt by humans. Mount Unzen is one of 19 active volcanoes in Japan designated as potentially dangerous and under constant observation by the Meteorological Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield Soldier, 3 Others Arrested in Military Weapons Thefts
DOC.TEXT: An Army soldier who had served in the Persian Gulf and three other men have been arrested in the theft of a huge cache of military weapons and explosives, federal and local officials said Saturday. The materiel seized Friday and Saturday from a warehouse and one suspect's home in Jacksonville included enough military explosives to destroy an entire city block, said Willi Ellison, agent in charge of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Jacksonville. Michael Tubbs, a U.S. Army Special Forces sergeant, had been brought back from Operation Desert Shield in Saudi Arabia within the past several weeks, Ellison said. Tubbs was already facing possible federal firearms and explosives charges in connection with a January 1987 incident at Fort Bragg, N.C., in which two soldiers were jumped and tied to a tree by two masked men who stole their rifles. He remained restricted Saturday to the base at Fort Campbell, Ky., Ellison said. Another soldier, Army warrant officer Jeffrey Jennett, has already been arrested and charged for the 1987 incident. Jennett was arrested in Charleston, S.C., on Thursday night and charged in federal court with assault with intent to commit felony theft and with stealing an M-16 rifle, Ellison said. Also seized Friday and Saturday were military weapons manuals, magazines describing how to wage urban warfare and make homemade bombs, and hate materials including videotapes of speeches by Adolf Hitler, Ellison said. ``All the literature focused on just a litany of hate against Jews, blacks and other minorities,'' Ellison said. ``They were well-equipped to engage in major warfare.'' ``Our preliminary indications are that these individuals are related to the KKK and the Aryan Nation, added John Gordon, deputy director of police operations at the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office. Arrested in Jacksonville on Friday were Michael Tubbs' brother, John, and Stephen Fussell, a 26-year-old handyman. Both men face federal firearms and conspiracy charges. The seizures and arrests resulted from a multi-state investigation by federal and local agencies focusing on the theft of weapons and explosives from military installations, Ellison said. ``This investigation spans several states,'' Ellison said. ``We're talking about Tennessee, Kentucky, North Carolina and Jacksonville.'' Much of the firearms and explosives are believed to have been stolen from U.S. Army posts at Fort Bragg and Fort Campbell, Ellison said. The arsenal recovered at John Tubbs' home and a mini-warehouse included Soviet AR-15 and U.S. M-16 automatic rifles, thousands of rounds of ammunition, an anti-aircraft machine gun, anti-personnel land mines, numerous handguns and shotguns, a 40mm grenade launcher, hand grenades, smoke grenades, tear gas, dynamite, blasting caps, booby traps and other high-explosives. Ellison and Gordon wouldn't comment on any possible motives the four men had for stockpiling such destructive material. ``The investigation is still continuing, and there may be more arrests in the future,'' Ellison said.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Settlement Reached In Bay Area Newspaper Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 2nd graf, `management accepted ...' with details of pact; picks up 3rd graf pvs, ` ``No strike! ...'
DOC.TEXT: A tentative settlement was reached Saturday to avert a strike at the San Francisco Bay area's three largest newspapers, negotiators for both sides said. Management accepted a union proposal at 10 a.m. after considering it during a short break in negotiations that went through the night, said Richard Jordan, chief negotiator for the San Francisco Newspaper Agency. The 45-month pact calls for a 3.5 percent to 4 percent annual wage increase for all unions, according to a report in Sunday's editions of the San Francisco Examiner. That amounts to $89 per week more over the course of the contract for craft unions such as printers and engravers, and $95 for reporters, editors and drivers. The contract also included benefits such as tax breaks for working parents and, for Newspaper Guild employees, the right to return to work part time after maternity or paternity leave. Workers also won new protection against hand and arm injuries that result from repetitive use of computers. ``No strike,'' Carl Hall, shop steward and Examiner reporter, told cheering newspaper workers gathered at strike headquarters Saturday morning. ``That's a group of people that were afraid they were going to strike but now know they aren't,'' said Tom Wheelan, a driver for the Examiner and the San Francisco Chronicle. The unions representing 4,500 employees at the San Francisco Examiner, the San Francisco Chronicle and the San Jose Mercury News had threatened to strike at 5 p.m. Friday. Instead, talks were continued after both sides agreed that progress was being made. ``We're happy for all concerned that there's a settlement,'' Jordan said. ``I think both sides made concessions.'' Jordan said the the federal mediator told him the union negotiating committee was unanimously recommending the contract to its members. Leaders of the 10 unions involved in the dispute planned to meet Monday morning to set dates for ratification votes. Union leaders indicated the votes would be taken after Thanksgiving. The agreement provides for an average $89 a week wage increase over the term of the contract, which expires in November 1993, Jordan said. Workers represented ranged from reporters and editors to delivery drivers and press operators. Current top-scale pay is $801 a week for reporters and editors, $669 for clerical and library workers and $675 for drivers. The three papers have a combined circulation of about 1 million. ``There were improvements in terms of child care and dependent care and flexible spending programs,'' which allow a portion of earnings to be shielded from taxes, Jordan said. Other details of the proposal were not immediately released. ``Apparently it's a good contract,'' Hall said. The negotiations didn't hamper production of the San Francisco Chronicle and the San Jose Mercury News, both of which were at the stands this morning. The afternoon San Francisco Examiner combines with the Chronicle to print a Sunday paper. The San Francisco Newspaper Agency runs all departments of the Chronicle and Examiner except for the news operations. San Francisco's last newspaper strike was in 1968 and lasted 55 days. The Mercury News was last struck in 1959, for four months.

Bush To Meet with Kohl, Mitterrand on Eve of Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 4 grafs with Bush arrival in Germany
DOC.HEAD: Precede PRAGUE
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, keeping the Persian Gulf crisis at the top of his agenda, flew to Germany today to meet with German Chancellor Helmut Kohl in advance of the opening of a 34-nation summit in Paris. Bush was met here in a cold rain by Kohl and the two leaders boarded a helicopter for a flight to Speyer, in Kohl's home region, where Bush was to attend an organ recital in Speyer Cathedral and speak in the town square. Kohl was then to take the U.S. president to his home in nearby Ludwigshafen. Afterwards, Bush was flying to Paris for dinner with French President Francois Mitterrand at the Elysee Palace. On Monday, Bush will join Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Paris for the signing of a landmark treaty to slash non-nuclear weapons in Europe. non-nuclear weapons in Europe. The signing ceremony will be followed immediately by the opening of a three-day meeting of the 34-nation Conference of Security and Cooperation, bringing former adversaries of the Cold War together in a new era of reconciliation. Today's stop in Germany retraces some sites visited by Gorbachev last weekend when he visited Kohl. Bush first will hear an organ recital at an 11th-century cathedral in Speyer and then go to Kohl's home in Oggersheim for lunch. A news conference is scheduled before the meeting ends. Aside from the gulf, a prime topic for discussion was the deteriorating political and economic situation in the Soviet Union, which is braced for a winter of extreme shortages of food and fuel. Kohl announced last week that Germany will provide emergency food aid to Moscow and he urged other Western nations to do the same. U.S. officials said the Bush administration is developing contingency plans to provide emergency supplies. From the start of his visit to Prague, Bush put a spotlight on the gulf crisis, linking the past year of revolution in Europe to the crisis in the Persian Gulf. ``I have this feeling in my heart that no peoples understand better what is at stake in the gulf than Czechs and Slovaks,'' Bush said. ``You know from your own bitter experience that the world cannot turn a blind eye to aggression. You know the futility and vain hope that aggressors can be appeased,'' he said. President Vaclav Havel said Czechoslovakia's own history ``has taught us ample lessons about the consequences of appeasement.'' One-third of Czechoslovakia's territory was ceded in 1938 to the Nazis in an unsuccessful attempt to prevent Adolf Hitler from conquering other countries. A huge crowd braved cold temperatures and biting winds to see Bush place a wreath at a memorial in Wenceslas Square, site of many turning points in Czechoslovakia's turbulent history. Czechoslovak television estimated the crowd at 150,000 but U.S. officials claimed the turnout was much larger. ``America will not fail you in this decisive moment,'' Bush promised the crowd. ``America will stand with you.'' He delivered the same pledge earlier in a speech to the Federal Assembly. And yet, Bush did not bring any major package of aid, offering instead a modest package of incentives to spur U.S. investment. Bush was unreserved in paying tribute to the reform movement that toppled Czechoslovakia's communist rule in a revolution that began last Nov. 17. ``That is why I am here today. We have not forgotten. And the world will never forget what happened here in this square where the history of freedom was written,'' the president assured the crowd.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Arms Agreement Approved
DOC.TEXT: NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators Sunday initialed a landmark treaty to slash non-nuclear weapons across Europe. The initialling approves the text of the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, scheduled to be signed Monday in Paris by President Bush, Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and representatives of 20 other nations in the two alliances. The leaders will be in Paris for a 34-nation summit of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The treaty, billed as the pact that formally ends the Cold War, limits each alliance to 20,000 main battle tanks, 30,000 armored combat vehicles, 20,000 artillery pieces, 6,800 fighter planes and 2,000 combat helicopters. The 70-page accord also regulates troops movements and permits mutual inspections. Negotiators late Saturday finalized another document that pledges a regular exchange of information on troop levels, arms systems and deployment and military budgets, Austria's national news agency APA reported. The pact is also scheduled to be signed Monday. The two documents were worked out after 20 months of negotiations. Negotiators originally sought a deal on troop reductions, but agreed to suspend the talks so the treaty could be ready for signing in Paris. Delegates plan to reconvene in Vienna Nov. 29 to discuss military personnel cuts. Hungarian officials said Thursday the Warsaw Pact, down to six members after German unification, would cease to function as a military alliance by July.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Killed In Traffic Accident
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. soldier was killed when a truck he was riding in lost its brakes and crashed in eastern Saudi Arabia, the U.S. military said Sunday. The soldier was the 47th member of the U.S. armed forces to die during Operation Desert Shield since deployment began Aug. 7, five days after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Most of the deaths have been in accidents. The soldier was from the 101st Aviation Brigade, 8th Squadron, the statement said. His name was not released pending notification of his family. The military said it was investigating the late Saturday accident. The five-ton truck was pulling a trailer and went off the road, the military said. A U.S. military statement said the driver was treated for shock and the other passenger suffered a broken finger. Their names were not released.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Barney Frank Hospitalized for ``Probable Heart Attack''
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Barney Frank has been hospitalized for treatment of a ``probable heart attack'' according to an official at a Boston hospital. The Massachusetts Democratic checked himself into Beth Israel Hospital in Boston on Saturday evening ``after experiencing chest pains,'' said Douglas Cahn, a spokesman for the congressman. ``He had a partial blockage in a major artery cleared last night and is resting comfortably,'' Cahn said. ``He is in intensive care,'' said Judy Taylor, hospital spokeswoman. Taylor said Frank ``is being treated for chest pains and a probable heart attack.'' Cahn said Frank ``was alert and conversing'' with family members who visited him last night. Officials and aides did not say how long the five-term congressman would be hospitalized.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Kohl Discuss Anti-Iraq Coalition in Brief News Conference
DOC.TEXT: President Bush visited with Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Sunday and called on Germany to help ``keep the coalition together'' in the Persian Gulf crisis. Bush said a united Germany should be an economic power and ``a tremendous force for peace.'' Bush said he'd made no special request of Kohl to bolster Germany's role in the anti-Iraq coalition. ``He made very clear that he'd like to see a peaceful resolution to this question, and so would I,'' Bush said. Kohl said, ``We talked about the challenge to the international community in the Middle East ... we were in agreement that it is very important indeed that the international community here stand together, stand fast,'' against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. In some radio remarks broadcast during Bush's visit, Kohl had stressed the need to exhaust negotiations before commencing any military action against Iraq. Bush told reporters he felt ``we're together with Germany'' on matters involving the Gulf crisis. Bush downplayed the differing emphasis, saying, ``I think we're in complete accord here.'' He added, ``We're not ruling any options out,'' and not ruling any in. Standing with Bush among umbrellas in front of Kohl's family home, the German chancellor said he ``would be most pleased to see as many American companies as possible'' investing in the region known until Oct. 3 as East Germany. Kohl said the German unification ``would not have been possible, indeed would not have been conceivable,'' without Bush's support. Kohl said ``the weather does not correspond at all to the kind of mood'' between him and Bush. Bush thanked Kohl for his ``extraordinary hospitality,'' and then the leaders took a few questions before giving in to the elements. Bush stopped in Germany on Sunday for an afternoon visit en route from Prague, Czechoslovakia to a three-day European summit in Paris. On Monday, Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev - along with the leaders of 20 other nations - were to sign a conventional forces treaty that reduces troop and arms levels in Europe. From Paris, Bush was flying to Saudi Arabia and Egypt, two key Arab allies in the Persian Gulf standoff against Iraq. He planned to spend Thanksgiving Day with U.S. soldiers taking part in the Desert Shield deployment.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Bush-Europe
DOC.TEXT: Following is a transcript of the news conference by President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl outside the German leader's home: Kohl: Mr. President, Mrs. Bush, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to thank you once again, very warmly, for having met with me here in my home region. The weather doesn't correspond at all to the kind of mood we're in and to the overall feeling. But unfortunately November in Germany means rain but the relationship between the Federal Republic of Germany and the United States of America is an excellent one. And this is due first and foremost to the personal involvement of President Bush. I've already said this in my short statement in front of Speyer Cathedral. The third of October, 1990, the day of German unity, would not have been possible, would indeed have been inconceivable without the help and support which we received from the Americans throughout the century - and we'll never forget this. Right now, over the next few years, over the next few decades, indeed - we, the united Germany want to do our utmost in order to foster and deepen this relationship, particularly among young people. We want to promote the exchange of students, of high school students, scientists, scholars, and this in the closest possible way. And obviously Mr. President, I would be most pleased to see as many American companies as possible investing in the new state - the new federal lander, which was formally the German Democratic Republic. I know that the President of the United States is a very busy man, indeed, but if perhaps in one of your next speeches in front of the Chamber of Industry and Commerce in the U.S., you were in a position to introduce a few remarks about the possibilities of investment in the Eastern part of Germany, in what was formally the GDR, I think that would be a very good and very beneficial thing. Today we talked about a number of issues where we think we can help each other. We exchanged views and we expressed agreement on the fact that we hope that the next GATT round, the Uruguay Round, may be a successful one. We're going to work on that one also over the next few weeks and we talked about the challenge to the international community in the Middle East, in Kuwait and in Iraq. We were in agreement here that it is very important, indeed, that the international community stand together here, stand fast and in a coalition, and this on the basis of the UN resolutions in the sense that we want to see respect for international law restored. And we were in agreement that it is of utmost importance to see a release of all hostages of all nationalities as soon as possible, and that this, indeed, was one of the most important prerequisites for any further talks. We also said that it was wished that negotiations would lead to a peaceful outcome of the situation there, but that these negotiations can only be successful if both sides want their success and if the consequences of this assault are removed. Again, Mr. President, thank you very much for coming here. Thank you, Barbara. And with all my heart, let me wish you all the best and the best of success in your very difficult office, and may God bless you. Bush: Thank you, sir, and may we thank you and Mrs. Kohl for your hospitality. There's something very special about conducting the kind of discussions we had within the home of two friends in a warm ambiance and in a setting that lends itself to frank and open discussions and agreement, as the Chancellor's outlined. And again, we're very grateful to you for this extraordinary hospitality. Thank you all very much. Q: Mr. President, in your prepared speech today, you said that Germany, a united Germany, must take responsibility for leadership in the world. What would you like to see Germany do in the Persian Gulf crisis? PRESIDENT BUSH: The German - I think exactly what Chancellor Kohl says - keep the coalition together. In my view, they are fulfilling their roles. And when I was talking about their leadership, clearly, anybody that takes a look at the map and understands the realities of the world knows that this united Germany is, and will be, a tremendous force for peace and certainly for economic good in the world. So I think we're together with Germany, both in the Gulf and - I have no - I made no special request of Chancellor Kohl at all. But I agree with him that this coalition is holding, and should continue to hold, and that's the best way to get a peaceful solution - send a solid signal to Saddam Hussein that his aggression will not be rewarded. Q: Do you think you see eye to eye? Kohl: (In English): One moment, please. Translator: Do you mind if we translated it? . Q: Do you think you see eye to eye on - Bush: Well, I've read what he's said, and I think we're in very close accord here. And we're not ruling out any options; we're not ruling any options in. I want to see a peaceful resolution of this question. Q: Mr. Chancellor in a radio address today warned - (inaudible) - the Gulf. Did he deliver a similar warning a similar warning to you? Bush: He made very clear he'd like to see a peaceful resolution to this question, and so would I. Kohl: Goodbye (in English). Bush: Thank you. A good way to do it. Thank you all.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Weather Forces Halt to Amphibious Exercise
DOC.TEXT: The key amphibious portion of the Imminent Thunder military exercise was called off Sunday because of bad weather, but troops in helicopters went ashore in a mock assault. Military officials said the seaborne assault would have gone off in wartime. ``In peactime, there are limitations and you don't want to lose anybody,'' said Maj. Gen. Harry W. Jenkins, commanding officer of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade. It was not immediately clear when the amphibious landing would be tried again. The helicopter assault and air exercises held on the fourth day of Imminent Thunder went well, Jenkins told reporters in a media pool covering the exercise. But Marine officers expressed disappointment that the key amphibious portion of the mock invasion, held about 100 miles south of the Kuwait border, was called off because of choppy waves reaching 4 to 8 feet high. ``Whenever I don't get to do everything I try to do, that's a disappointment,'' said Lt. Col. Robert P. McAleer, commanding officer of the battalion of Marines involved in the drill. ``If we had had a real-world situation, you always stretch the parameters of what you can do and what you can't do.'' The troops in the helicopter assault left the USS Guam despite winds of 20 to 25 mph. Hovercraft aboard the USS Gunston Hall, situated 25 miles from shore, were not dispatched because of high waves. Among those who came ashore on helicopter gunships were 34 Saudi Arabian Marines. U.S. and British warplanes provided simulated air support and cover for the troops. No live ammunition was fired, officials said. Imminent Thunder, as the six-day exercises in the gulf are named, involves about 1,000 troops and 1,100 aircraft - the largest force of warplanes yet assembled for a Desert Shield exercise. The drill is meant to emphasize gaining control of the skies, which would be critical to smash Iraqi defenses. A key objective of the amphibious assualt had been to practice an attack from ships 30 miles from shore.

DOC.TEXT: President Bush today prodded Germany to play a bigger role in the Persian Gulf showdown with Iraq, urging this newly united and powerful nation to ``take responsibility for leadership'' in the world. But German Chancellor Helmut Kohl cautioned against a military solution, urging that ``everything be exhausted that there is to exhaust with negotiations.'' ``Whoever believes the problem can be solved militarily must consider not only the mission, but the end of the whole undertaking,'' Kohl said in a German radio interview aired shortly after Bush arrived. Under pressure from the United States and other allies, Kohl has agreed to provide $2.2 billion for the American and allied troop buildup in the gulf. But citing constitutional barriers, Germany has not sent any troops. ``As Europe forges a new future, Europe must not turn inward,'' the president said in prepared remarks. ``Just as a new Europe must look beyond its borders so too must a united Germany take responsibility for leadership in our commonwealth of nations,'' Bush said. Joining ohl to answer questions later outside the chancellor's home, however, Bush said he had ``made no special request'' of the German leader during their private talks about the Middle East. When asked what he meant by asserting that the newly reunified Germany should assert leadership, he replied, ``In my view they are fulfilling their role.'' He said he agreed with Kohl about the importance of remaining unified against Saddam Hussein. `` ... So I think we're together with Germany in the gulf,'' Bush said. Bush said Kohl ``made very clear he'd like to see a peaceful resolution to this question, and so would I.'' Following the news conference, Bush departed Germany for a short flight to Paris, where he joins 33 other leaders Monday for a conference formally ending the Cold War. Earlier, the president was to deliver a speech to an outdoor audience but was forced to cut it short because of a heavy downpour. ``The rains are coming so I will conclude mercifully,'' Bush said. ``The nations of Europe have overcome conflict and the partitions that are its bitter fruits,'' Bush said in the prepared text. ``Now by working together, in the spirit of unity and determination, we can help achieve the same for the world.'' Bush arrived at Ramstein Air Force Base to be greeted by Kohl and a crowd of 400 people braving pouring rain and powerful winds. The two leaders and their wives then flew by helicopter to the 11th century cathedral town of Speyer in Kohl's home region. Bush began his eight-day tour of Europe and the Mideast on Saturday with a one-day stop in Prague, becoming the first American president to visit Czechoslovakia. He told reporters flying with him from Prague to Germany that his visit was ``very moving and very emotional and very good.'' Bush said Havel's denunciation of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait ``should be well noted around the world. This country (Czechoslovakia) has learned it means to be taken over. It just redoubles my conviction that aggression can't stand.'' Kohl said it was very important to maintain Western solidarity in isolating Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein and he urged intensive efforts so that Iraq quickly frees all foreign hostages. Once the hostages are free, he said, ``the chance for negotiations is far greater.'' Asked about the firing on Friday of Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai I. Rhyzhkov by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Bush said, ``Very interesting. We'll have a chance to talk to Mr. Gorbachev about all of that.'' Bush and Gorbachev will meet over breakfast Tuesday in Paris amid a 34-nation summit of East and West countries. The two leaders also will get together Monday morning for the signing of a historic treating slashing non-nuclear weapons in Europe. Bush said the arms treaty ``seems to be overshadowed by what's happening in the gulf. But it is a significant milestone.'' On another subject, Bush was asked about reports that William Bennett, who resigned as national drug control director, will become chairman of the Republican National Committee. Bush smiled and said, ``We're not discussing that. A lot happens when I leave.'' Bush's first stop was an organ recital at the Speyer Cathedral, from where he was proceeding to Kohl's home for lunch. In his speech Bush said the revolutions in Europe had brought ``a peaceful conclusion to the divisions of the Cold War.'' And yet, Bush said, ``New challenges to peace and freedom are arising from distant shores. ``If the world rewards naked aggression; if we ignore the proliferation of the technologies of mass destruction; if we conclude that these challenges are not everyone's concern - then we put at risk everything we have achieved,'' Bush said. The president said that ``no people on earth are more thrilled by your achievement than your friends in America. ... German unity came, in part, because Americans stood by the free people of Berlin, from the daredevil pilots of the airlift to a young president who made his bold declaration on a windswept day before the Wall.'' He was referring to President John F. Kennedy's 1963 speech at the Berlin Wall. Bush also saluted Kohl as ``the man who united Germany.'' Kohl is facing national elections in two weeks in a bid to become the first chancellor of a united Germany. Aside from the gulf, a prime topic for discussion with Kohl was the deteriorating political and economic situation in the Soviet Union, which is braced for a winter of food and fuel shortages. Kohl announced last week that Germany will provide emergency food aid to Moscow and he urged other Western nations to do the same. The Bush administration is developing contingency plans to provide emergency supplies. From the start of his visit to Prague, Bush put a spotlight on the gulf crisis, linking it to the past year of revolution in Europe. ``I have this feeling in my heart that no peoples understand better what is at stake in the gulf than Czechs and Slovaks,'' Bush said. President Havel said Czechoslovakia's own history ``has taught us ample lessons about the consequences of appeasement.'' One-third of Czechoslovakia's territory was ceded in 1938 to the Nazis in a vain attempt to prevent Adolf Hitler from conquering other countries. ``America will not fail you in this decisive moment'' of the difficult transition from communism to a free market economy, Bush promised a giant crowd which braved bad weather to attend a rally at Wenceslas Square Saturday. ``America will stand with you.'' And yet, Bush did not bring any major aid, offering instead a modest package of incentives to spur U.S. investment.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Extremists Kill 43 in Weekend Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Sikh extremists demanding independence for Punjab state killed at least 43 people in a series of attacks over the weekend, police and news agencies reported Sunday. At least 2,830 people have been killed by Sikh militants in Punjab so far this year. It is the highest yearly toll since the violent separatist campaign started in 1982. A Sikh religious leader and five devotees were fatally wounded by three Sikh gunmen at a worship service Saturday night at Balachaur, 100 miles southeast of Amritsar, Press Trust of India said. In another Saturday night attack, four Sikhs approached a police checkpoint where a Sikh constable greeted them as relatives and invited them to meet his colleagues, a district police official said. While the group was having tea at the checkpoint near Hararkalan, 18 miles north of Amritsar, one of the visitors pulled out an assault rifle and killed five of the six policemen, said Paramjit Singh, the senior superintendent of police. The Sikh constable fled with the killer, said Singh, who spoke by telephone from district police headquarters in Majitha. He said four of the slain policemen were Sikhs and the fifth was a Christian. Shortly after sunrise Saturday, Sikh gunmen ambushed a group of Hindu fundamentalists exercising in a park on the Punjab-Haryana state border. Nine men were slain and a 10th died of shock during the attack at Quillewali, 120 miles south of Amritsar, police said. Sikh extremists staged a series of other attacks around Punjab state during the weekend. The victims included Sikh policemen, their relatives and a Hindu man who was pulled off a bus, Press Trust and United News of India reported. Sikhs, whose faith has roots in both Hinduism and Islam, form only 2 percent of India's 880 million people, but they have a slight majority over Hindus in Punjab. Amritsar, in northern Punjab, is the site of the holiest shrine in the Sikh faith, the Golden Temple. The militants want to establish a Sikh nation, called Kalistan, or Land of the Pure, in the prosperous farming state on thet Pakistani border. The militants accuse Hindus, who make up 82 percent of India's population, of discriminating against them politically and economically. Initially, they generally targeted Hindus. But in recent years they have escalated attacks against Sikhs who serve in the police forces or who are not considered militant enough.

DOC.HEAD: Orthodox Priest Murdered in Ukraine
DOC.TEXT: A Russian Orthodox priest in the Ukraine was shot and killed by unknown assailants, the Tass news agency said Sunday. It was the second killing of an Orthodox priest in three months. Tass quoted police as saying that Ivan Kuz, a priest in the Western Ukrainian village of of Bynliv, was hit by three bullets fired at close range. His body was discovered in a forest by residents of the nearby town of Vizhnitsa. The report said the priest was seen driving his car to a religious service in a neighboring district. ``The burnt car was discovered near the village of Valyava,'' Tass said. The motive for the slaying was not known. Tass said police had ruled out robbery. In September, Alexander Menn, a prominent Russian Orthodox priest and writer who was persecuted for his evangelical activities, was bludgeoned to death with an ax while on his way to church. Menn's body had been found near his house not far from a railway station in Zagorsk, the site of an ancient monastery that is a showplace of the Russian Orthodox Church, Tass reported at the time. Menn's slaying has not been solved.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Marks Cold War's End, But Threat of Gulf War Looms
DOC.TEXT: East and West meet this week determined to set a peaceful course for Europe after four decades of tension, but the celebrations of the Cold War's end are clouded by threat of war in the Persian Gulf. Leaders of the 34 nations of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe converged Sunday on Paris, where their three-day summit opens Monday. ``For the first time in 40 years,'' said Secretary of State James A. Baker III, ``Europe will be meeting and discussing and planning without an artificial East-West divide to block progress.'' The nations meet ``at a time when they have an absolutely new European space in front of them, an absolutely new state of things,'' said Vitaly Ignatenko, spokesman for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, describing the summit as the most important international event since World War II, said it will ``design the architecture of Europe for the century to come.'' On Monday, the leaders of NATO and the six nations of the lifeless Warsaw Pact will sign a treaty slashing arsenals of tanks, helicopters and other conventional weapons. The text of the final summit document has been worked out in advance, ensuring closer cooperation among the onetime adversaries. U.S. and French officials say major last-minute modifications are unlikely. Talks on the fringes of the summit could eclipse the conference itself, focusing on the crisis spawned by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Just as Europe settled into its embrace of peace, the gulf crisis put much of the world on a heightened military footing. President Bush will meet privately with a host of leaders allied with the United States against Iraq, including Gorbachev, French President Francois Mitterrand and British Prime Margaret Thatcher. The summit will produce sideshows as well. Some leaders arrive in Paris under severe domestic political pressure. Thatcher and Mitterrand's premier, Michel ocard, both face votes by Parliament members during the summit that conceivably could topple them. Gorbachev continues to struggle against rebellious politicians and economic troubles. Dozens of prominent French people, including a pop singer and a Catholic bishop, are organizing a rally in Paris on Monday to protest the deployment of Western troops in the Gulf. Monitoring protests will be one of many tasks facing the 10,000-strong security force contingent assigned to the summit. Anti-terrorist squads, including rooftop snipers, will be deployed, and thousands of policemen will seal off several blocks around the conference center, barring any pedestrian or motorist who lacks a special pass. The Conference for Security and Cooperation in Europe was created with the signing of the 1975 Helsinki Final Act. One result of the summit will be to institutionalize the CSCE, setting up a small secretariat in Prague, a center in Vienna for the prevention of conflict, and an office in Warsaw to help monitor elections. The summit document also includes the recommendation that the heads of member states meet at least once every two years, their foreign ministers annually and senior officials even more often. France is proposing creation of some sort of conciliation process to resolve differences between member states regarding ethnic minorities. Several participants have stressed that they do not want too firm a structure for the CSCE to prevent overlapping with NATO and the European Community. ``Let's avoid creating useless structures, whether they be duplicates of those that already exist or whether their functions are insufficiently defined,'' Dumas said. A conservative Swedish newspaper, Svensa Dagbladet, said in an editorial that a possible European confederation ``is best built on the foundation Brussels has laid (the European Community), rather than the looser CSCE process.'' Between the formal summit sessions - primarily speeches by the 34 leaders - and the private consultations, most of the participants will have little leisure time. The one major social occasion on the agenda is a dinner Tuesday at the chateau of Versailles, preceded by a ballet performance.

DOC.HEAD: Mass WWII Grave Found Near Site of `Bridge Over the River Kwai'
LaserPhoto BK1
DOC.TEXT: A mass grave has been discovered near the site where more than 100,000 Asian slave workers and Allied prisoners died building a railroad for the Japanese during World War II. The remains of several hundred people have been dug up since Tuesday, when the excavation began. It is being carried out by the Pothipawana Songkroh Foundation, which for religious reasons wants to provide proper burials. Several dozen workers were digging Sunday in a sugar cane field in Kanchanaburi province, about 70 miles west of Bangkok. One skull was left out overnight - but workers first covered it with paper so it would not be cold. About half the small plot has been excavated. The mass grave is about three miles from a bridge made famous in the 1957 Hollywood movie, ``Bridge Over the River Kwai,'' which celebrated the heroism of the war captives. A foundation official, Santi Assawaseeyotin, said it appeared the bones had been ``dumped into the ground, because they were found in some disorder.'' Santi said the bones were dating back to the World War II era. ``We believe they were bones of Asian people as the skulls found were not big,'' he said. ``There also were children's bones.'' He said the remains were being brought to the foundation's office in Bangkok, where they will be cleaned and cremated. There was no direct evidence the bones belonged to the World War II prisoners. No such remains have been found in Kanchanaburi in recent years. Also recovered were metal plates and bowls; on the back of several were written Made in Japan or Made in Hong Kong. The Bangkok Post newspaper said some had the year 1939 imprinted on them. More than 100,000 Chinese, Indian, Malay, Burmese and other Asian slave laborers lost their lives building the railway in 1942-43, along with more than 16,000 British, Dutch, Australian, American, and New Zealand prisoners of war. They died of disease, malnutrition, exhaustion, beatings and executions. The Japanese had the 268-mile line connecting Thailand and Burma built for their planned invasion of India. Ladda Matcha, 38, who lives near the grave, said the owner of a motorcyle repair shop also near there recently dreamed that the dead told him they could not breathe and asked him for help. The man contacted the foundation, whose representatives secured permission from the landowner to dig, Mrs. Ladda said. The owner knew of the remains on her plot, but used it to grow sugar cane. Mrs. Ladda's mother, Pab Borngern, 77, said the Japanese constructed a military camp and tunnel in the area during the war. ``When the Indians (workers) died, they just carried them into the hole they dug up,'' she said. ``At the place where they found the bones, that was thousands of people buried there. Those peple died because of fever.'' The Bangkok Post quoted the landowner's sister, Lek Pailom, 64, as saying field hospitals for Asian slave workers were in the area. ``Every morning, the Indians dug a hole in this area to bury dead bodies in the evening,'' she said. ``Some days, two or three bodies were buried, some days more than five.'' ``This happened throughout the period of the railway construction,'' she said. The discovery of the remains came just before the annual 11-day River Kwai Bridge Festival. This major tourist attraction of special shows and exhibitions is scheduled to begin Friday. In March, Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan responded to objections by Australian veterans groups and Prime Minister Bob Hawke by barring shows that a tourism company planned along the railway. They were to have featured Japanese soldiers supervising work gangs.

DOC.HEAD: Five Centuries of Moscow's Art Treasures Go On Display in Washington
DOC.TEXT: Some of Moscow's most precious art treasures went on display at the Smithsonian Institution in a major U.S.-Soviet venture celebrating the rich cultural heritage of the Soviet capital over the past five centuries. The exhibition's more than 200 objects span the creative life of Moscow from a late 15th century icon portraying the ``Miracle of St. George and the Dragon'' to modern abstract paintings by Vasily Kandinsky and Kazimir Malevich. The show was welcomed Friday to Washington by Robert McC. Adams, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, and Soviet Minister of Culture Nikolay Gubenko, who called it a ``great event'' in fostering closer ties between Soviet and American citizens. Viewing the exhibit will give Americans a chance to ``feel the Russian soul'' after centuries of mutual ignorance and estrangement, said Gubenko, a former movie director and artistic director of Moscow's Taganka Theater, where he still performs as an actor on weekends. The paintings, sculptures, engravings, religious icons, porcelains, jewelry, ancient weapons and armor, jeweled masterworks of gold and silver, historic costumes, maps and other objects were loaned by the State Kremlin Museums, the State History Museum, the State Tretyakov Gallery and other collections in Moscow. Among them is an altar cross of gold and precious gems made in the Kremlin workshops in 1562 and presented by Czar Ivan IV - ``Ivan the Terrible'' - to the Solovetsky Monastery in northern Russia. Other objects include a 16th century steel helmet that once belonged to Ivan's son and heir, and a plate made in 1694 of gold, emeralds and rubies that was given to young Tsarevich Aleksey, son of Peter the Great, by his grandmother. The exhibition, titled ``Moscow: Treasures and Traditions,'' will appear in the International Gallery of the Smithsonian's S. Dillon Ripley Center on the National Mall until Feb. 3. This is the second and final stop for the show, which opened last summer in Seattle. Underwritten by The Boeing Co., the show was organized by the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service and the Soviet Ministry of Culture in association with the Seattle Art Museum and the Seattle organizing committee of the 1990 Goodwill Games.

DOC.HEAD: Socialists Beat Conservative Coalition in Faeroese Poll
DOC.TEXT: The main opposition party made a strong showing in parliamentary elections in the Faeroe Islands, and the party's leader said he planned to form a new government, Danish public radio said Sunday. The incumbent conservative coalition led by Prime Minister Jogvan Sundstein lost four of its 21 seats in Saturday's balloting, while Former Prime Minister Atli Dam's Social Democrats gained three, the radio said. The Social Democrats now hold 10 of the 32 legislative seats in the self-governing territory, which is under the Danish crown. Sundstein's rightist People's Party holds only seven. Dam, who was prime minister for three four-year terms between 1970 and 1988, said he planned to form a new coalition government with one or two of the other main parties. ``We will talk with all the parties. There are many coalition possibilities,'' Dam said in a radio interview. There was no immediate comment from Sundstein. The Faeroese constitution forbids minority administrations, and the government must command at least 17 seats. The elections, only the second early poll in 40 years, were called to break a political deadlock on how to rescue the foundering economy. Sunstein's People's Party, which came to power in the 1988 ballot and formed a coalition with the Unionist and the Republican parties, dropped one seat in the election. The volcanic archipelago of 18 islands located about halfway between Scotland and Iceland in the North Sea has a population of 47,000. The six parties represented in the Loegting, or parliament, are split both ideologically along left-right lines and on the question of separation from Denmark. At 85.9 percent, turnout among the 330 eligible voters was slightly lower than it had been in the past four elections.

DOC.HEAD: Famous Moscow Bakery Struggles to Survive
LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Rain seeps through cracks in the ceiling and spiders spin webs above vats of dough at Bread Factory No. 14, once the Filipov Bakery, whose raisin buns have been famous since czarist times. Women and teen-agers toil at open ovens, with no protective gloves or masks. They work in a rat-infested neighborhood and live in crowded dormitories. Managers of the 150-year-old bakery, one of 33 in Moscow, say they want to make improvements but are caught between the dissolving structure of Soviet Communism and a new economic order not yet formed. The bakery's plight illustrates the difficulties Soviet businesses and workers face in converting from a centrally planned to a market economy. Leonid Vorobyev, the bread factory's 47-year-old director, is trying to figure out how to fit into the plan the Soviet legislature adopted Oct. 19 for switching to a market economy. He also is pondering how to attract foreign capital to modernize the bakery, how much to pay his workers and how much to charge his customers when prices are freed from their artificially low fixed levels. Vorobyev is worried, and so are his employees. In a stormy meeting with the workers, who demanded to know what their salaries and positions would be, he said: ``Give me results and the money will be there.'' The manager, who has been in the baking industry 25 years, said in an interview afterward: ``We and they are afraid of a (free) market. What will it be like?'' Under current conditions, it's amazing the bakery produces anything edible. Economic planner Tatiana Zimina said the 200 workers make 20 tons of baked goods daily, using worn-out equipment 20 years old. There are 19 varieties, from white bread to the famous raisin rolls. Rats that infest the neighborhood are attracted by the aroma of baking bread and by flour spilled on the floor. Bakery workers, 70 percent of whom are women, have no machines for moving sugar, margarine and flour from heavy steel vats to the mixers, so they do it by hand. Those who work the unsealed ovens have the worst job. Blasts of hot air pound their faces. The only ventilation is a window that cannot be fully opened because too much heat would be drawn from the ovens. The women, some with scars from burns on their arms and hands, slit the tops of molded loaves with knives and slide them into the ovens on trays. Because of the difficult conditions, pay averaging $324 a month, and a six-day week, the bakery has trouble attracting workers and is 40 people short. Most employees are older women or teen-agers. A vacant apartment building next to Bread Factory No. 14 looks as if it had been bombed or is in the process of being razed, with broken glass, dirt and plaster piled knee-deep on the floors. In August, a construction crew digging nearby cut a natural gas pipeline, forcing the bakery to shut down for a few days. Vorobyev and his fellow managers want to hire their own drivers, bypassing unreliable state truckers, and are negotiating with foreign companies to renovate the plant. They also are negotiating with the Soviet bureaucracy to improve working conditions and keep more of the profit, most of which now goes to government ministries. Workers got pay raises in September. Ms. Zimina said her goal is for the workers to own the factory. ``We dream about privatization,'' she said, but added that bureaucrats stand in the way. The Russian republic's government approved private ownership of many factories in September, but the bread ministry later excluded large bakeries, including Factory No. 14. Another difficult problem is changing the psychology of workers, many of whom seem disinterested in increasing production or streamlining the operation. The factory's bookkeeper, a powerful employee in a Soviet business, is 78 and not enthusiastic about change, Ms. Zimina said, adding: ``How can she do anything new or fight the bureaucracy?''
Here is a brief look at President Bush's schedule for Monday, as he continues his eight-day trip to Europe and Saudi Arabia:

Breakfast with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Signing of a treaty cutting conventional forces in Europe. Opening session of summit meeting of leaders from the 34 nations in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. News conference.

DOC.HEAD: A Supreme Court `Photo Op' Goes Uncaptured
DOC.TEXT: Call it the photo opportunity that got away - and a rare one at that. When Justice David H. Souter replaced the retired William J. Brennan, the court's nine members gathered for an official portrait taken by a photographer for National Geographic magazine. Photographers and camera crews from various news organizations also were invited for the session but waited in another room until the official shot had been taken. At one point, while the National Geographic photographer changed some equipment, the prim and proper Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, standing behind a seated Justice Byron R. White, struck a pose found in countless family albums. She stealthily raised her right hand close to White's head and extended her index and middle fingers. To eyewitnesses standing in front of the black-robed justices it fleetingly appeared that White, the court's gruff senior member, had grown rabbit ears. O'Connor, who once agreed with a friend's assessment that ``with Sandra there ain't no Miller time,'' may be heeding the much-publicized advice she received years ago from former Washington Redskins running back John Riggins at a black-tie dinner. ``Loosen up, Sandy baby,'' she was told.
DOC.HEAD: Not Much to Argue About
DOC.TEXT: Since beginning its 1990-91 term last month, the court has been spending less time on the bench hearing oral arguments due to a shortage of available cases. The justices' increased selectivity last spring is why. The number of cases that have arrived since Oct. 1 - more than 1,800 - is running slightly higher this term than last. And the justices have granted full review to 44 so far, a few more than last term. But when the current term began, only 57 cases were available to be argued, compared to the 81 available the previous October, and the 105 the year before. Some court watchers are grumbling about those cases granted. The legal issues they raise seem comparatively lackluster, some say.
DOC.HEAD: Don't Call Him Chief
DOC.TEXT: The court is very close to announcing the man selected to head its 76-member police force. The new top cop's title, however, will not be the same as his retired predecessor. ``Chief of Police'' has been scrapped in favor of ``Inspector.'' It seems one chief is enough for the court, although the duplication never bothered Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. The same may not have been true for retired Chief Justice Warren E. Burger. During his tenure, the police force's leader was called Captain.
DOC.HEAD: Souter Has Three Clerks, No Permanent Secretary
DOC.TEXT: Justice Souter now has three law clerks and has hired a fourth who will join his staff soon. The three already on board, and their respective law schools, are Paul Salamanca of Boston College, John Sullivan of Columbia University and Peter Spiro of the University of Virginia. Salamanca has to be one of the nation's luckiest young lawyers. When he took a job with Souter some months ago he expected to be working for a newly seated and little-known member of the Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals.

DOC.HEAD: President Makes First Visit to Christian Heartland Since Election
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi crossed into Lebanon's Christian heartland Sunday, his first such visit since his election a year ago and a dramatic illustration that the city's dividing lines are eroding. The Syrian-backed Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic, attended Mass in the chapel of Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir's seat in Bkirki, 12 miles north of Beirut. A convoy of jeeps carrying troops swept ahead of the president's shining black, bullet-proof Mercedes as it passed through the Museum crossing, once the only link between the mainly Moslem and Christian sectors of the sprawling metropolitan area. The motorcade sped without incident through streets lined with scores of battle-scarred, high-rise apartment buildings used as sniper nests during 15 years of civil war. At Bkirki, known for its soaring statue of the Virgin Mary, Hrawi sat in the front row of worshipers. Sfeir warned in his sermon against the ``domination by one side over the other, which could tip the balance required for peaceful coexistance.'' Hrawi and Sfeir then held a 40-minute conference behind closed doors. The president said afterward, ``We have reached an understanding over all issues facing the nation. My government will be fair to all.'' The patriarch's sermon appeared to reflect fears among the Maronite community, their ranks depleted by a year of fighting in their heartland, that a peace plan brokered by the Arab League to end the civil war might herald Moslem domination of power. It was within the framework of that peace accord that Hrawi was elected president by parliament last Nov. 24. In September, he signed into law constitutional reforms envisaged by the plan that gave Moslems an equal share of power with the Christians. The Maronites, the largest Christian sect, have dominated the government, army, parliament, judiciary and financial sector since Lebanon gained independence from France in 1943, when they were thought to be the majority. The Moslems, who now make up about 55 percent of Lebanon's 4 million inhabitants, have pressed for equality in the civil war that claimed more than 150,000 lives since 1975. On Oct. 13, Hrawi's army backed by Syrian troops crushed an 11-month mutiny against his government by rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun. That removed the last obstacle facing the peace plan. The Syrians maintain 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. After Aoun's ouster, Hrawi's government dismantled Beirut's Green Line and reopened nearly all crossings between the Moslem and Christian sectors. It also set a deadline of midnight Monday as a deadline for Moslem and Christian militias to evacuate the capital and its environs to proclaim a unified ``greater Beirut.''

DOC.HEAD: Protests as Cabinet Approves Religious Legislation
DOC.TEXT: The Cabinet overrode opposition protests and approved legislation Sunday to restrict ``indecent advertising'' and public transport on Jewish holy days. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir agreed to the measures to draw the ultra-orthodox Agudat Israel party into his coalition government A coalition agreement signed Friday also provides for restrictions on abortion and a ban on the breeding and sale of pork, in line with Jewish religious law. The curbs on advertising and transport were approved for parliamentary scrutiny with only one vote against, by Agriculture Minister Rafael Eitan. Agudat Israel has been promised speedy passage of the laws through the Knesset (parliament). The law on transport will forbid buses to operate between sundown Friday and sundown Saturday and high holidays - a measure strongly opposed by those who travel to and from remote settlements on weekends. Currently, buses generally do not run on holy days. But those serving outlying areas have to set out before the holy day is finished in order to meet their schedules. The law on advertising is supposed to curb nudity on public billboards, and carries a six-month prison term for offenders. Such an ad is defined in the coalition agreement as ``a picture of naked men and women, a picture containing a stimulation of sexual arousal or a temptation to commit sexual relations, or a picture of nude parts of the body which offends the religious belief or feelings of the public... or which harms minors or their education.'' Bus stops and billboards featuring scantily clad women have frequently been defaced by orthodox Jews seeking to impose their moral code on Israel's secular majority. Fifteen members of the liberal Shinui (Change) party protested outside the Cabinet office, and the socialist Kibbutz Arzi movement, representing some 80 socialist kibbutzim (collective farms), warned the legislation could lead to a ``cultural war'' between secular and religious Jews. Shinui legislator Avraham Poraz claimed Shamir's Likud Bloc was ``selling the secular public to Agudat Israel,'' and that the laws ``will take us back to the Middle Ages.'' Health Minister Ehud Olmert acknowledged the laws were unpopular, but said: ``In the present political circumstances, we have no choice but to pay this price.'' Roni Slavtau, director-general of the Advertisers' Union, said the curb on advertising was ill-defined. ``What is indecent? If they define as indecent ads of high esthetic value that fulfill different cultural criteria of the 20th century, there will be some disagreement here,'' he said. Legislator Shulamit Aloni, head of the left-wing Citizen Rights Movement, said the new laws were aimed ``to force us into chains of coercion. I am very, very worried.'' Little criticism was heard from the main opposition, the Labor Party, which had offered Agudat Israel much the same legislation when it was trying to form a coalition with the party. Agudat Israel's four seats give Shamir's right-wing coalition a majority in the 120-member Parliament. Since it was formed in June, the government has ruled with 60 seats, plus tacit support from the two members of the rightist Moledet (Homeland) party. However, the respite may not last. Eitan's two-member Tzomet (Crossroad) party is dissatisfied that the government has not met his demand for electoral reform. Shas, a six-member religious party, is threatening to quit the coalition, saying it is dissatisfied with the government's handling of Arab-Israeli peace efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed in Scattered Violence
DOC.TEXT: Seven people died in scattered violence nationwide, including two after a clash between police and protesters in Johannesburg, police and news reports said Sunday. African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, meanwhile, urged supporters to step up a campaign of strikes, protests and other mass action to force an end to apartheid. ``We are a forgiving people but we are not slaves,'' Mandela told 15,000 cheering, singing people at a stadium south of Johannesburg. ``My call to you is to intensify the struggle. ... Boycotts, stayaways, strikes civil disobedieance, marches and meetings are all legitimate peaceful means of struggle.'' Police fired tear gas, rubber bullets and birdshot on Saturday when about 700 protesters in the Johannesburg city center ignored an order to disperse and hurled bottles and stones. Two people died of gunshot wounds in a hospital late Saturday night, police said. At least fifteen people were injured, including eight protesters, six police officers and a traffic officer, police said. The government-run South African Broadcasting Corp. said one policeman was seriously injured and six police vehicles were extensively damaged. The protesters had planned to march against black leaders in townships, but police banned the march. Many blacks allege the councils collaborate with the white-led government to perpetuate the apartheid system of segregation. President F.W. de Klerk has pledged to end apartheid and negotiate a new constitution that would give the black majority a share of political power. But Mandela on Sunday accused the government of calling for reform while trying to preserve political and economic power for the white minority. A man was shot to death Sunday in the black township of Soweto while on his way to a rally by the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party. Police said the unidentified assailants fled. Fighting pitting Zulu supporters of Inkatha against Xhosa and other blacks linked to the ANC has killed more than 800 people in Johannesburg townships since August. The clashes have eased recently. In an unrest report for the previous 24 hours, police said Sunday that three people died in separate incidents throughout the country. One man was shot to death in Wembezi township in eastern Natal Province, and the bodies of two people were found in Germiston township near Johannesburg, and in Nkelethu township in eastern Cape Province. The Broadcasting Corp. also reported unrest in the Crossroads township near Cape Town that left one man dead and 20 squatter dwellings burned. The township has been hit by violence over poor living conditions. Laws segregating residential areas remain in effect, and most blacks live in squalid townships.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Cracks in British Nuclear Submarines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Deletes 3rd graf to remove redundancy.
DOC.TEXT: At least two and possibly three of the four nuclear-powered submarines that carry Britain's Polaris nuclear missiles have developed cracks in their cooling systems, newspapers reported Sunday. They said repairs to correct the fault will probably reduce the number of patrols and might halt them entirely. The four subs carry 16 Polaris nuclear missiles each. It is policy to have at least one on patrol at all times. If none can be at sea, Britain has no effective nuclear deterrent until new, more powerful submarines to carry U.S. Trident missiles are ready in 1995. The Observer weekly said there are cracks in the nuclear reactor cooling systems of two of the vessels, HMS Revenge and HMS Renown. It said that a third, HMS Repulse, may also be cracked. ``When the remaining Polaris submarine, HMS Resolution, returns from patrol later this month, there may be no boat ready to replace her,'' The Observer said. The Ministry of Defense on Sunday denied the nuclear capability had been undermined by the reactor problem. ``The Polaris deterrent is being maintained, at sea and on patrol,'' a department spokesman said on condition of anonymity. He declined to discuss ``technical'' matters, or the operational deployment of the Polaris fleet. The Observer attributed its information to lawmaker John McFall and defense and industrial sources. McFall, a Scot, has contacts among the submarine personnel at their base on the west coast of Scotland. The Sunday Times quoted McFall as saying serious problems existed in three of the four submarines. It said senior officials at the Defense Ministry admitted the defects. The weekly quoted John Large, a nuclear engineer, as saying the trouble was caused by metal in the reactors that had hardened and become brittle. In all, Britain has 22 nuclear-powered submarines.
