Five other submarines - Warspite, Churchill, Conqueror, Valiant and Courageous - are being decommissioned and scrapped. At least two of them had cracks in the reactor cooling systems.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas City's Term Limit Could Create Some Wild Politics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Katheryn in 12th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Voters wanted new faces. And that's what they're going to get. Political observers anticipate as many as 50 candidates may run for nine elected municipal posts being vacated because voters approved a two-term limit this month. Moreover, some black and Hispanic residents plan to challenge the term limit in court. While incumbents warn that the limit could put more power in the hands of city hall bureaucrats, others say they're looking forward to a needed switch. ``It'll be a breath of fresh air,'' said Charles Wheeler, a former mayor who helped get the issue on the ballot. ``It's going to be a zoo,'' countered the Rev. Emanuel Cleaver, one of nine incumbents who will lose seats on the 13-member council. Unlike term limits recently approved in Oklahoma, Colorado and California, Kansas City's measure is retroactive. Anyone who already has served two consecutive four-year terms can't run in April, when the municipal election will be held. The nine incumbents losing jobs have spent between eight years and 21 years governing the city of 450,000. Three already had planned not to seek re-election, including three-term Mayor Richard Berkley, who serves as an ex officio voting council member; and Cleaver and another council member, both of whom plan to run for mayor. None said they would wait four years and run again, as the law allows. Besides those running for mayor, just one said he will definitely seek another political office. At least two are looking for other work. Incumbents are not the only ones worried that the new council, made up of beginners and lame ducks, will be too weak to control a large city staff. Katheryn Shields, a first-term council member who plans to run again, said council members already struggle against an unresponsive bureaucracy. ``Now we'll have a situation where the staff, if they disagree with a council member on something, can simply say, `Hey, they're going to be gone in two years or three. We can wait them out,''' she said. Others worry that term limits will dilute the power of the city's minorities. Four of the soon-to-be-ousted incumbents are black and one is Hispanic. The other four are white, including the mayor. Citizens in two districts plan to file a lawsuit claiming that the term limits violate the federal Voting Rights Act. They say it was unfair for voters citywide to decide the fates of candidates from particular districts. The mayor and six other council members are elected citywide, and six are elected by district. ``Many people in those (black) districts feel it will be a long time before they can elect candidates who had the same kind of experience and influence, and maybe never,'' said Cleaver, who is black. Still others think the term limit won't have much effect on the city's underlying political structure. They say the powerful political clubs that endorse candidates will simply reach down to the next available person. ``Everybody acts like 50 philosopher-kings are going to step forward to run for office,'' Shields said. ``But there aren't 50 philosopher-kings out there. It probably will be the same caliber of people.'' She contends the limit will merely succeed at getting rid of certain council members who are disliked citywide but considered virtually unbeatable in their districts. To Wheeler and others, that would be enough. They say the current council is unaccountable to voters - neglecting to ask their opinion on how tax money should be spent and using favoritism to decide what city projects should be done. In addition, one city council member served a 30-day federal prison sentence in 1988 for failing to file a federal income tax return in 1983. ``We need a clean slate,'' Wheeler said. ``This is going to give us that.''

DOC.HEAD: Scars Remain 10 Years After 87 Died in MGM Grand Hotel Fire
DOC.TEXT: Ten years after crawling to safety from his hotel room through 21 floors of choking smoke, Dennis Casey will be in church to mark the day the MGM Grand Hotel burned. Time and a $50 million remodeling job to the 26-story resort - now known as Bally's - have dimmed memories of one of the nation's worst hotel fires, which killed 87 people Nov. 21, 1980. But mental scars remain for survivors like Casey. ``You always wonder why you lived and they died,'' the Pittsburgh public relations executive said. ``I have nightmares about it, I'm not ashamed to admit that. I see a therapist for it on a regular basis.'' Explaining that he'll attend church Wednesday, as he has done every anniversary of the fire, Casey said: ``I go at the exact Eastern time of the fire and I say a prayer for those that lived and died. It's my way of remembering the people in the hotel.'' The 2,800-room resort now boasts one of the finest fire safety systems of any high-rise. And tough state retrofit laws passed after the disaster forced other Nevada hotels to also install top-of-the-line sprinkler and fire safety systems. But on the morning of the blaze, the then 7-year-old resort had no sprinklers and an array of code violations. Casey and some 4,000 others were inside when a short circuit in a delicatessen pie case sparked a smoldering blaze that went unnoticed for hours. In a restaurant next to the deli, a vacationing Illinois firefighter, Kurt Schlueter, was sitting down to breakfast with fellow firefighter Dave Beshoar and his brother when guards first noticed the fire and began to evacuate the restaurant. Two other friends were on their way down from a 12th-floor suite the five had rented for a weekend of fun and gambling in Las Vegas. The two were later found dead. ``A security guard came in said there was a small problem next door and asked us to leave,'' said Schlueter, a lieutenant in the Western Springs, Ill., Fire Department. ``By the time we got to the front of the restaurant, we could see smoke piling up on the ceiling and we knew what was happening.'' A few people kept gambling in the casino, but the firemen and security guards hustled most of the guests toward the exits as the main floor began filling quickly with dark, acrid smoke. By the time Schlueter and the Beshoars had gotten to the front door, they had been forced to their knees by the smoke. Suddenly, shortly after 7 a.m., the lights went out and the blaze exploded into a fireball that flashed across the casino floor at an estimated 17 to 19 feet a second. ``Dave and I were the last ones out before the fireball hit,'' Schlueter said. ``We heard a loud click, all the lights went out and it was pitch dark. All of a sudden there was a massive heat that pushed us clear out the door. If we hadn't been right at the door, we would have been trapped in there.'' A handful of people were killed by the fireball, but the toxic smoke from the casino's synthetic furnishings would prove far more deadly. Smoke billowed up elevator shafts to the top of the hotel and was trapped on the upper floors of the tower. Of the 61 people who died in their rooms or in hallways, 60 were on the 19th floor or above. Figuring he would die if he stayed in his room, Casey doused himself with water from a bathtub and put a wet towel around his face. Opening his door, he saw the body of a woman lying in her doorway. ``I crawled to her body and felt her neck for a pulse,'' Casey said. ``She was dead. It was the first time I fully realized that I might die and I began to cry. You've got to remember that no more than five minutes earlier I had been asleep.'' Six months later, the MGM had a $5 million sprinkler and safety system, and the melted, charred slot machines had been replaced by a glittering new casino. Actor Cary Grant was the first guest to check in.

DOC.HEAD: NATO, Warsaw Pact Initial Conventional Forces Accord
With AM-Arms Treaty, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators from NATO and Warsaw Pact countries initialed an agreement Sunday to detroy tens of thousands of non-nuclear weapons and build a peaceful Europe on the ruins of Cold War conflict. The ceremony in Vienna's Hofburg Palace, the site of negotiations for the past 20 months, means the treaty is ready to be signed by President Bush, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other heads of state Monday in Paris. ``From this treaty, the Soviet Union is ceasing to become a militarized state with all the consequences of that - economic, political and social,'' said Oleg A. Grinevsky, Soviet ambassador to the talks. ``All the wealth of our society can be used for the benefit of the people instead of building up an expensive and sometimes useless war machine.'' Before initialing the 160-page treaty, representatives of the 16 NATO and six Warsaw Pact countries exchanged thick packets of information on the size of their arsenals in Europe. Officials said they could not yet release the figures in those documents, but they said that more than 100,000 pieces of military hardware would probably be destroyed. ``No battle in the history of mankind ... destroyed such an immense number of tanks, armored combat vehicles, artillery and combat aircraft,'' Grinevsky told reporters. No agreement was included on numbers of combat soldiers. A U.S.-Soviet understanding on the number of soldiers each may have in Europe was overtaken by German unification, and negotiators will go back to work in Vienna Nov. 29 in an effort settle that question. The Warsaw Pact countries - the Soviet Union, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria - will have to destroy many more weapons than the Western alliance to reach the quotas, which are equal for both sides. The countries will have 40 months to eliminate the weaponry from the moment the last nation ratifies the treaty. Destruction of such a large number of weapons will make it difficult for any country to attack another, said U.S. Ambassador James Woolsey. The United States and its allies began the negotiations in March 1989, determined to cut into the Soviet Union's ability to launch a surprise attack, Woolsey said. But about six months later, a tide of revolution began that swept away Eastern Europe's hard-line Communist rulers. The arms talks took on a broader meaning as the Warsaw Pact allies broke away from Soviet domination and began defining an independent position in the heart of Europe. Officials of Warsaw Pact countries now say the Eastern alliance is likely to end its military business in mid-1991 and transform itself into a loose political alliance. But even if the Warsaw Pact ceases to function militarily, its individual countries still are bound by its terms. The treaty limits each alliance to 20,000 main battle tanks, 30,000 armored combat vehicles, 20,000 artillery pieces, 6,800 fighter planes and 2,000 combat helicopters. The accord also regulates troop movements from both alliances and permits mutual inspections across Europe from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains.

DOC.HEAD: High Winds, Waves Force Cancellation of Mock Amphibious Assault
LaserPhotos D0D1
DOC.TEXT: The Imminent Thunder maneuvers were supposed to be a dress rehearsal for war, but 10-foot waves forced the U.S. Marines to postpone the amphibious landing portion of a mock invasion Sunday. Officials said the landing wold probably have gone off in a real war. One hovercraft from the USS Gunston Hall was launched in the choppy Persian Gulf, but it sputtered in a heavy spray and sometimes disappeared behind waves before the seaborne assault was scrapped. ``It's real disappointing,'' said Gunnery Sgt. Mike Pupkar, who services the hulking landing craft. ``But it isn't worth hurting people and wrecking equipment on a day like (this).'' The landing was rescheduled for Monday morning. Meanwhile, 14 CH-46 Sea Knight helicopters from the USS Guam ferried about 400 troops to shore at exactly the scheduled time Sunday morning. Among them were 36 Saudi Arabian marines. The wind and helicopter blades kicked up stinging sheets of sand. Overhead, hundreds of U.S., British, French and Saudi attack jets and surveillance planes provided cover and air support. No live ammunition was fired. Maj. Gen. Harry W. Jenkins Jr., commanding officer of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, told reporters the exercise was a success despite the inability to use the hovercraft to assault a barren stretch of Saudi beach. ``One of the training objectives for this exercise was to bring all these allied forces together and make sure we're all talking to one another,'' Jenkins said. ``I'm pleased we've had as few glitches as we've had. ... We don't want to risk anybody if we don't have to.'' The commander of the battalion of U.S. Marines that was supposed to board hovercraft expressed disappointment when the exercise was aborted. ``Whenever I don't get to do everything I try to do, that's a disappointment,'' Lt. Col. Robert P. McAleer said. ``Anytime you get cut out of an exercise it's not a good day for you.'' Despite being unable to use landing craft to get Marines ashore, officers said it didn't affect the outcome of the mock invasion and changed their mission only slightly. ``By the time naval gunfire got done with this area, there wouldn't be much opposition left,'' said Marine Capt. David Dysart, 30, a company commander whose troops were assigned the task of securing a road junction. Under U.S. military rules, this section of the six-day exercise was covered by several media pools. The Marines have done three other amphibious practices on the Arabian peninsula, but this one was the first on Saudi soil and it involved the highest concentration of warplanes assembled since Operation Desert Shield began. According to news reports, Imminent Thunder was supposed to be held as close as 10 miles from the Kuwaiti border. The actual landing was about 100 miles south of Kuwait, reportedly after complaints from Iraq and in the United States that it might provoke Saddam Hussein. ``They moved the goalposts,'' said Marine Maj. John Toolan of Brooklyn, N.Y. The amphibious assault was supposed to commence 25 miles offshore in a tecnhique called ``over the horizon'' because shore can't be seen when the hovercraft are launched. But winds of 20 to 25 mph stirred up choppy waves estimated at 4 to 10 feet high. Marines were first forced to endure a tedious wait, then got the word of cancellation over a loudspeaker. ``If it was the real thing, we could probably go,'' said Cmdr. Bill Marshall, captain of the USS Gunston Hall. But, he said, ``We're not going to put them in the water if it's not safe to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Survivor: Rising Anti-Semitism Adds Urgency to Message
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `The was...', to CORRECT `The' to `He.'
DOC.TEXT: The news of 1990 saddens Robbie Waisman yet strengthens his resolve. When the Holocaust survivor reads about the desecration of Jewish cemeteries in France, former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke making a strong bid for the U.S. Senate, and neo-Nazis in the Pacific Northwest, he wonders: ``If this happens when there are still survivors, what will happen when we're gone? ``The world lost 11 million people, of which 6 million were Jews. ... To think people look at that and still have that hate. It leaves one completely aghast. Why? Why?'' Now a hotelier in Vancouver, British Columbia, he has spent much of the past seven years reminding people of the Nazis' slaughter of 6 million Jews. He was one of several speakers being featured during the two-day conference that began Sunday, marking 45 years since the end of World War II. ``Captive and Free: Lessons of the Holocaust for Today and Tomorrow'' was organized by the Interfaith Council on the Holocaust, which is devoted to preserving the memories and lessons of those years of genocide. By the spring 1945, Waisman at 14 had spent nearly one-third of his life in concentration camps, the last eight months at Buchenwald in Germany. He lost both parents and four brothers in the Holocaust. When U.S. troops arrived to liberate the camp, he recalled in a telephone interview last week, he thought he was dreaming. When two soldiers with brown skin approached, he thought he was dreaming. He had never seen black men. In 1983, he saw pictures of soldiers in a magazine article about the liberators. One of them was Leon Bass, a former Philadelphia high school principal who, Waisman learned, was active as a speaker on the Holocaust. He was one of the black men Waisman had seen 38 years before. Waisman called Bass - who was a corporal in the 183d Engineer Combat Battalion, part of the Patton's Third Army - and they got together and talked for hours. ``We have sort of shared a moment in time where we just glanced at each other,'' Waisman said, ``and 40 years later we met again and became very close friends.'' Bass was at first dubious that Waisman truly remembered him; he certainly remembered no faces. ``When I came into the camp, I did not see him,'' Bass said. ``I saw all the walking dead in front of me. He was looking out the window, all skin and bones.'' Bass said he has seen enough in 65 years not to be disheartened by current events. ``If people don't stand up to racism, we would go downhill,'' he said. ``Maybe we haven't moved as far ahead as we might have moved, but if we hadn't tried, we would be farther down the hill.'' John Raines, the Interfaith Council's co-chairman and a Temple University religion professor, said a rash of anti-Semitic incidents in Europe made Sunday and Monday's conference more timely. ``Clearly what we are seeing in Eastern Europe is the revival of very ancient hatreds,'' he said. As the communist bloc dissolves, he said, people revert to old nationalistic loyalties and traditional religions. ``An unfortunate part of those traditional religions in Eastern Europe and Russia is anti-Semitism,'' he said. Waisman, who moved to western Canada to get as far away as possible from Europe and the memories, broke nearly four decades of virtual silence in 1983 after hearing that a teacher in Alberta was telling students the Holocaust never happened. He now speaks frequently on the subject. ``You have no idea how gratifying it is,'' Waisman said. ``I speak about the camps and I have to dig back into my memory. It's painful as hell .... But when you speak to the students, and they come up afterward, and they write you letters, the pain is worth it.'

DOC.HEAD: Greek Catholic Archbishop Goes to Iraq About Hostages
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Syrian-born Catholic leader Archbishop Hilarion Capudji left for Baghdad on Sunday to ask Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein for the release of all foreign hostages. Upon his departure from Rome, Capudji stressed that he would place special emphasis on the release of Italian hostages because of ``Italy's consistent political support of and moral and humanitarian treatment toward the Palestinian people.'' Since it occupied Kuwait on Aug. 2, Iraq has been holding hundreds of foreigners to try to prevent an attack by the U.S.-led alliance in the Persian Gulf. The 68-year-old archbishop is the spiritual head of the 3,000-member Melchite-rite Catholic community of Jerusalem. Melchite Catholics are Arab Christians who formed an eastern-rite branch of the Roman Catholic Church. The branch recognizes the primacy of the pope but enjoys a wide degree of independence from the Vatican. Many Christian members of the Palestinian Liberation Organization are Melchite. Capudji also said he hopes to convince Hussein that war in the gulf would have ``apocalyptic consequences'' and that a peaceful solution must be found to the crisis that began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. With the archbishop were members of Italian Catholic organizations and peace groups.

DOC.HEAD: Military to Reform in Three Stages
With AM-Arms Treaty, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet military plans to cut its manpower and weaponry to make the armed forces more efficient and less of a burden on the state, the chief of staff was quoted as saying Sunday. A draft of the 10-year, three-stage restructuring plan has been forwarded to the Supreme Soviet legislature, said Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, the armed forces chief of staff. He made his comments in an interview with the military newspaper Red Star. The newspaper also quoted an official identified as only Col. M. Ponomarev as saying: ``Today, we have no apprehensions, nor do we suspect any nation of planning a war against the Soviet Union. This has allowed the Soviet leadership to adopt a new military-political doctrine of reasonable sufficiency.'' The first stage of the restructuring, which depends on the signing of the Geneva and Vienna arms agreements, calls for the total withdrawal of Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Mongolia and Germany by 1994, Moiseyev said. Under the plan, civil defense units will be scrapped, along with the military's road construction units and some other construction units. The second stage, to take place from 1994 to 1995, calls for the formation of a new strategic grouping of armed forces on Soviet territory, a reorganization of the central command structure, and a realignment of military districts. The third and final stage calls for a 50 percent cut in strategic offensive weapons by the year 2000. It envisions enhancing Soviet military efficiency by combining units with similar tasks and weapons. It calls for eventually cutting the size of armed forces from the current 4 million to at least 3.2 million. About 1,300 generals, 22,000 officers, and 250,000 non-commissioned officers would return to civilian life. Moiseyev said the restructuring will make the armed forces ``less of a burden on the state and more efficient at the same time'' and would reduce it ``to the corresponding level of real military danger and with the new political, economic and social environment.'' In the draft plan, pay raises will be given next year to all ranks. Ordinary soldiers, who now receive only $13.50 a month, will get $54 to $63. Officers and non-commissioned officers, whose pay averages $360 to $720, will get pay increases of about 25 percent. The draft will continue, Moiseyev said, but alternative service will be allowed for those who object to service on religious grounds. Ponomarev said the conditions were right, both domestically and internationally, to carry out military reforms. Although there is no immediate threat of war with the West, he said, the previous stockpiling of weapons still posed a danger. ``We cannot remain indifferent to this and therefore disarmament has become the call of the day,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Time Mag Personalizes Its Covers, For You, Jane Smith!
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For 3 p.m. release EST
DOC.TEXT: Time magazine will make each of its 4 million subscribers a cover subject this week. Through the magic of computers, the magazine has incorporated each reader's name into its cover design to illustrate a story on junk mail. ``Hey, Jane Smith. Don't miss our really interesting story on the junk mail explosion!'' reads a sample cover from the Nov. 26 issue, released Sunday. Newsstand copies will carry the cover line: ``Hey, you at the newsstand ....'' The cover story says that 63.7 billion pieces of third-class mail were delivered nationwide in the past year. But the tactic works. The article says that last year, 92 million Americans responded to direct-market pitches, a 60 percent jump in six years. Over the course of a lifetime, the average American professional will devote 8 months to sifting through direct mail offers, the article said. About 43 pounds of junk mail is generated for each adult American. Forty-four percent is thrown away, unopened.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapping Reporters Is Drug Mafia's Latest Intimidation Scheme
DOC.TEXT: Like hundreds of other Colombians under threat from drug traffickers, Francisco Santos traveled in a chauffeur-driven, bullet-resistant car. But the precautions weren't enough. On Sept. 19, a group of gunmen forced the car to stop, killed the driver and abducted Santos, news editor of Colombia's biggest-selling newspaper, El Tiempo. Santos, 28, is one of nine journalists who have been abducted in the past three months by the Medellin cocaine cartel. The traffickers, having already resorted to bombings and assassinations, are attempting a more subtle form of intimidation. Some reporters belong to Colombia's most influential families. In one communique, the cartel threatened to kill its hostages if the government launches a new offensive against traffickers. An anonymous caller to El Tiempo warned that a dead journalist would be ``sent to the presidential palace in a plastic bag'' if President Cesar Gaviria didn't establish direct negotiations with traffickers. Why are reporters the target? ``The cartel wants access to the media,'' said one source close to the investigation. He asked not to be identified. Cartel leaders have said the kidnappings are a response to human rights abuses by police. They said security forces in Medellin, Colombia's second largest city, were torturing and murdering their associates. Whatever the reason, the abductions are taking a heavy toll not just on the kidnapped reporters and their families, but on journalism itself. Aside from the hundreds of people murdered by drug traffickers, ``freedom of expression has been our most noteworthy casualty,'' wrote Rafael Santos, Francisco's brother, in a recent editorial. ``The drug war has been a Colombian journalist's nightmare,'' he added. The Medellin gang has killed about 30 reporters, including Guillermo Cano, publisher of the Bogota daily El Espectador. That newspaper's main offices were all but destroyed by a powerful bomb blast set off by drug traffickers last year. Many reporters are afraid to write stories about drugs. Those that do write don't use bylines. Journalists who speak out against the cocaine mafia have grown accustomed to guns, bodyguards and armored cars. ``Those who have shown the most bravery in working under these conditions are either dead or in exile,'' El Espectador columnist Jose Salgar wrote recently. Until the first week of November, many Colombians believed the kidnapped journalists would soon be returned to their homes. A group of political and church leaders were engaged in a public exchange of letters with a lawyer for the Medellin cartel. The lawyer, Guido Parra, outlined the cartels' demands: amnesty, an end to extraditions and U.N. mediation in Colombia's drug war. The polite exchange between Parra and the church and political leaders offered hope of a solution. But the leaders insisted that the drug barons' demands could not be considered until all the hostages were released. The cartel responded Nov. 7 by abducting journalists Maruja Villamizar and Beatriz Guerrero from their car in northern Bogota. The kidnappers murdered the journalists' driver, Angel Maria Roa. In short order, the negotiations were called off. All along, the Gaviria administration has refused to negotiate with the cartel. ``No issue is debatable under force,'' said one senior official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Another casualty of the kidnappings has been the optimism which accompanied Gaviria's ascension to the presidency on Aug. 7. Former president Virgilio Barco left office saying the cartel had been ``severely debilitated.'' Peace talks between the government and armed groups - both on the left and right - appeared to be bearing fruit. The country was preparing for a national assembly to reform its 104-year-old constitution. The violence, which had claimed tens of thousands of Colombian lives in the past decade, seemed to be diminishing. One of Gaviria's first moves as president was to prohibit extraditions to the United States of drug traffickers who surrender. The kidnappings seemed an unlikely response to Gaviria's concessions. But they underscored the cartel's ability to make life difficult for many Colombians, despite a series of government victories in the drug war.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader Arrives at Summit with Uncertain Prospects
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev enters the 34-nation East-West summit fresh from a major government crisis at home and with uncertain prospects for what could be a hungry and tumultuous Soviet winter. Gorbachev said before leaving Moscow that the Conference on Security and Coopration in Europe would be ``major landmark in the history of our continent.'' But the real action was back in the Soviet Union. On Thursday, Gorbachev became the first Soviet leader ever summoned before parliament to account for his failures. And on Friday, he proposed a new government structure. The disarray within the Soviet empire could hardly contrast more sharply with the first CSCE summit. That session, held in Helsinki in 1975, produced the so-called Helsinki Accords, which defined the human rights obligations of the participants and ratified the presence of Soviet ground forces and pro-Moscow regimes throughout Eastern Europe. Soviet power and prestige may have reached their peak during that year. It was the summer of the U.S.-Soviet joint space mission, a few months after the inglorious American withdrawal from Vietnam, the year a pro-Soviet government came to power in Angola, a time when Communists were strong in Italy, France and Portugal. For now, Gorbachev has turned his attention to the meeting in Paris, where the scheduled highlight is a treaty that ostensibly slashes East-West conventional armies in Europe. The pact in fact consecrates the retreat of most Soviet ground forces behind their own borders by the end of 1994. The collapse of the Soviet Bloc over the past 15 months has outpaced conventional forces negotiations, and diplomats already are talking about a follow-up treaty to keep up with events. Another highlight of the 34-nation conference was to be the signing of a non-agression pact between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Kremlin-led Warsaw Pact. This agreement, too, would have seemed impossible three years ago, but today recognizes established fact. Gorbachev arrives in Paris straight from Rome, one of the many West European capitals he has visited in the past month seeking financial and moral support. President Bush already has told officials to draw up plans to rush food to Moscow if needed, and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher commissioned a fund to convey British industrial know-how to the Soviet Union. No one knows whether such aid will bolster Gorbachev. Confronting the revolt this week in the formerly tame Supreme Soviet legislature, Gorbachev announced not simply that he was dumping the unpopular Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, but that he was changing the very structure of government. The Council of Ministers that Ryzhkov heads will be scrapped, along with the newly created Presidential Council. Gorbachev announced plans to enhance the Federation Council, a body that previously had little power but has the virtue of including representatives from the 15 Soviet republics. By boosting the power of the Federation Council, Gorbachev effectively embraced a proposal put forward by his rival, Russian President Boris Yeltsin, to form a government made up of representatives from the 15 Soviet republics. Gorbachev's solution, however, did not seem to move the Soviet Union closer to his stated goal of a government of laws rather than unchecked power, and fit the pattern of his increasingly stopgap measures to prop up central power. Although the Helsinki summit of 1975 ratified the borders of postwar Europe, those borders are again in flux. The demolition of the Berlin Wall just over a year ago removed a frontier that two generations of Soviet leaders struggled to preserve. Now the borders of the Soviet Union itself are threatened, as the three Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, along with the Caucasian republics of Armenia and Georgia seek outright independence, and Moldavian nationalists agitate to reunify with Romania. In Russia, by far the largest Soviet republic, Yeltsin and his Russian government are waging what promises to be a successful campaign for control of state-owned oil and gas fields, as well as other natural and industrial resources. The Ukraine, the second largest Soviet republic, is also getting restive, and is likely to win enhanced rights if it agrees to Gorbachev's proposal to sign a new Treaty of Union, replacing the 1924 charter that united the Soviet republics. Despite the promise of Western aid, it is not clear what if anything Bush and the other leaders will be able to offer the Soviet Union, or whether there is anything they could do to bolster Gorbachev's collapsing authority. ---= EDITOR'S NOTE: Bryan Brumley, Moscow bureau chief for The Associated Press, has covered Soviet affairs since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Urge Administration To Help Stem Repression in East Timor
DOC.TEXT: More than half the members of the House are asking Secretary of State James A. Baker III to use U.S. influence to reduce the ``atmosphere of fear and repression'' in the Southeast Asian nation of East Timor. A group of 223 House members signed a letter to be sent to Baker on Monday that calls attention to reports of arrests, detention, torture and other human rights violations on the island nation in the last year. ``We believe that it is of great importance that United States' concern over the Timor situation be stressed at this time,'' the letter said. East Timor is a former Portuguese colony that was annexed by Indonesia in 1975. The group likened Indonesia's takeover of East Timor to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. The lawmakers, including 53 Republicans, cited reports of detentions of pro-independence demonstrators following an October 1989 visit to East Timor by Pope John Paul II. They also said human rights advocates were beaten by Indonesian police after their meeting with the U.S. ambassador to Indonesia during a visit to the country in January. The letter also points out the potential for periodic cycles of hunger and malnutrition brought on by ``Indonesian military policies such as restrictions on where Timorese villagers can farm their crops.'' ``The United States should use its influence to help ensure that humanitarian needs of this nature are promptly addressed,'' the lawmakers said. Additionally, the United States ``should support a process of peace talks that could lead to negotiations without preconditions among parties directly involved,'' the letter concluded. The letter was spearheaded by Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger.

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Malcolm-Jamal Warner thinks he's ready for life after ``The Cosby Show'' - behind the camera. ``I've been preparing to be a director since I was 17,'' Warner says in an interview published in the Nov. 24 issue of TV Guide. ``I knew I had to learn it.'' Warner, now 20, has starred as Bill Cosby's son, Theo, on the hit series for seven years. ``Where do I go from here? To think that I reached my peak as a teen-ager would be a sad and scary thought.'' He directed his first episode of ``The Cosby Show'' last spring and is set to direct two more episodes this season. He's negotiating to direct a feature film, already has directed six music videos and is co-producing four television children's specials. --- DALLAS (AP) - The glare of success has started to melt the mysterious facade of Dallas-based rapper Vanilla Ice, whose rap single ``Ice Ice Baby'' hit No. 1 on the pop chart. The Dallas Morning News described numerous contradictions in Vanilla Ice's record-company biography and interviews in a story in Sunday's editions. The 22-year-old white entertainer in a genre dominated by blacks has described a colorful teen-age background of gangs, motorcycles and rough-and-tumble street life in lower-class Miami neighborhoods. But the newspaper quoted numerous sources as saying he was their classmate at R.L. Turner High School in Carrollton, an affluent Dallas suburb. The student is identified in yearbooks as Robert Van Winkle. Vanilla Ice would not comment on whether his given name is Robert Van Winkle, but said he went to Turner in his junior and senior years. He has said repeatedly that he won three national motocross championships for Team Honda in Florida. A Team Honda representative said there is no record of a team member named Robert Van Winkle or Vanilla Ice. A representative of the American Motorcycle Association said its records show a racer named Robert Van Winkle from Carrollton, but he never won a national title. Asked if Vanilla Ice had embellished his biography, publicist Elaine Schock said: ``Yeah, he may have exaggerated a little. ... I've known artists who have done much worse. A lot of artists do this.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Nearly a quarter of a century has passed since the last time Topol played Tevye, the dairyman hero of ``Fiddler on the Roof,'' but he's not complaining about repeating himself. ``I really have enjoyed it,'' the 55-year-old actor said of the show's Broadway revival, set to last for three months. ``I am now at the age I used to aim for. The years that went by since I first played it have been an experience that made me enjoy it more than when I was younger,'' the Israeli actor said in an interview in Sunday's editions of The New York Times. The play last appeared on Broadway in 1964. Topol starred in the London production in 1967. He's well aware that ``Fiddler'' has since become a popular high school play. ``I've met 200 guys who played Tevye. You can't surprise anyone with the story,'' he said. --- BURCHARD, Neb. (AP) - The winner of a $23.1 million Lotto America prize has moved to a new life in Colorado - with no forwarding address, thank you - to escape donation seekers, investment counselors and even relatives. Edwin Frahm, 51, won the prize in June while he was working on a construction project in Topeka, Kan. His wife was working at the time as a housekeeping supervisor in Beatrice, Neb. They quit their jobs and stayed on a Burchard-area farm owned by Frahm's mother. But a month ago, they decided to get out of Nebraska, according to Frahm's son, Lee Frahm, who lives in the Denver area. He said his father doesn't want to talk about the move, and he won't reveal the location of the Colorado ranch his father bought. Friends and neighbors in the Burchard area say the Frahms left to escape the harassment that followed the monetary bonanza. ``There were so many people coming after they won it. People trying them, begging for money. You'd get tired of that after a while,'' a neighbor said. Wayne Cacek, another neighbor and friend, said relatives were pressuring Frahm to buy his mother's farm. ``He figured the best thing to do was to move on and let someone else take over the home place,'' Cacek said.

DOC.HEAD: Nationalists Accuse Communists of Vote-Rigging
DOC.TEXT: Nationalist parties accused Communists in the Yugoslav republic of Bosnia-Hercegovina of rigging elections Sunday. The contest could make or break Yugoslavia's future as a federation. Foreign observers, in Sarajevo to monitor the republic's first free vote since 1938, confirmed there were irregularities. But they said they were probably because of poor organization. ``Many people came to vote, but were not on the lists, which caused a lot of nervousness,'' said Joseph D. Dwyer, of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University. ``I don't think it was a bad intention by any party, but just poor organization,'' added Dwyer, who visited 15 polling stations. Western observers said Saturday they were impressed by the organization of the balloting. The republic's electoral commission also said it was checking the claims. Voter turnout was reported low. Only 30 percent of the voters had been to the 5,000 polling stations by 3 p.m. (9 a.m. EST.) Polls opened at 7 a.m. and closed at 8 p.m. (2 p.m. EST). First official results were not expected until the end of the week. In a rare show of unity, Serb, Croat and Moslem nationalist parties accused Communists of tampering with electoral lists just before polling stations opened. Bosnia-Hercegovina, an ethnic melting pot of 4.2 million people whose feuds sparked World War I, is a microcosm of Yugoslavia itself. The republic is at the heart of the country's bitter rivalries both geographically and politically, and it could play a pivotal role in deciding Yugoslavia's political future. Radovan Karadzic, leader of the Serbian Democratic Alliance, one of three nationalist parties, claimed thousands of non-Communist voters were struck from lists and replaced by known Communists from outside Bosnia. Stjepan Kljuic, leader of the Croatian Democratic Union and Alia Izetbegovic, president of the Moslem Union for Democratic Action, backed Karadzic's claims of fraud. The reformed League of Communists, currently in power, denied the charges. ``The (nationalist) parties are inventing accusations against us because they know they will lose,'' League leader Nijaz Durakovic said. He predicted that Communists would capture at least 30 percent of the republic's 240-seat bicameral assembly. A small group of voters gathered at the electoral commission's headquarters after they found their names missing from electoral lists in Sarajevo. ``I've lived at the same address for 20 years and I always voted in single-party elections. Now, mysteriously, my name is gone,'' said retiree Dragan Djordjic. The state news agency Tanjug said problems with the voting lists were evident in northwestern Bosnia. Some 3 million voters could choose among 1,551 candidates from 40 parties for parliament and among 28 candidates for the seven-seat republican presidency. No single party seems likely to win a clear majority in Sunday's first round. First official results were expected late next week, and run-off elections will be in two weeks. In the struggle to shape the country's future, the Western republics of Croatia and Slovenia, where center-right parties ousted Communists in spring elections, are pushing for more independence, or even secession, from the federation. They are pitted against Serbia and the other poorer, southern republics who want a strong central government. Serbia and Montenegro are still in Communist hands ahead of Dec. 9 elections. Bosnia has so far charted a neutral course between the two feuding blocs as mounting ethnic tensions in Yugoslavia's six republics and two provinces have pushed the federation to the brink of collapse. The vote has set the nationalist parties against the reformed Communists and federal Premier Ante Markovic's Alliance of Reformist Forces, promoting cross-ethnic policies and a united Yugoslavia. Sarajevo is best known as the site that sparked World War I in 1914 after Austrian Archduke Franz Ferdinand was assassinated by young Serbian nationalist Gavrilo Princip.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Headmaster Shot in Schoolyard, Called Collaborator
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with details, correct information on school. Pickup 7th pvs, `The deaths...'
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian headmaster was shot dead in front of his pupils in a schoolyard Sunday for allegedly collaborating with Israel, Arab reports said. Another Arab was killed in the occupied West Bank village of Jabaa by armed Palestinians, the army said. Masked assailants shot the headmaster, 31-year-old Saleh Salem Hijazi, in the head as he finished an English lesson and was leaving the class in the Rabah el Adaweyeh girls' high school in the Gaza Strip town of Rafah, the reports said. The army confirmed the killing. Graffiti painted on the school walls claimed responsibility on behalf of a group calling itself el-Fahed el-Aswad, which means Black Leopard. Itim, the Israeli news agency, said it was the third time an alleged collaborator has been killed inside a Gaza Strip school in recent months. Arab reports said the assailants in Jabaa were collaborators who were armed by Israel to defend themselves. The dead man was identified as Muhammad Sharaim. The deaths brought to 302 the number of Arabs killed by fellow Palestinians, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Some 773 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli army and civilian gunfir in the 35-month-old uprising. Fifty-two Israelis have died in the violence. At least five Palestinians were wounded by Israeli army gunfire in scattered stone-throwing riots in the occupied territories, including an 8-year-old girl hit in the hand, Arab reports said. At the weekly Cabinet meeting, Economics Minister David Magen proposed halving the Arab labor force in Israel by fining employers who hire non-Israelis. With unemployment running at 9 percent, Magen believed his proposal would open 50,000 jobs for the country's 92,000 people out of work, including 19,000 recently arrived Soviet immigrants. More than 100,000 Palestinians from the occupied territories work in Israel. According to Magen, about 70 percent of them do not have the special work permits needed to prove they have no criminal or anti-Israel political background. A spate of Arab knife attacks on Jews has prompted calls for Arab workers to be replaced by Soviet immigrants. Magen told Israel army radio his proposal would boost the West Bank and Gaza Strip economy as ``tens of thousands will prefer to find work near their homes because they can't work by Israeli law in Israel.'' Left-wing legislator Dedi Zucker said Jerusalem shopkeepers were being forced to fire Arab employees and post signs saying ``We don't employ Arabs here.''

DOC.HEAD: Pipe Bombs Explode at Motel and Department Store, No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A pipe bomb hidden in a borrowed stereo blew up when the stereo was plugged in at a motel and an apparently unrelated bomb exploded on a store roof, police said Sunday. ``It's kind of unusual to have them so close together,'' said Sgt. Bob Ensley, but he doubted the explosions were at all connected. The booby-trapped stereo went off when Kathy Dastrup plugged it in at her motel room. Ms. Dastrup, 32, suffered only minor injuries because she was bending near a table at the time, said Ensley. An acquaintance, 21-year-old Herman Nathaniel Belkins, who had borrowed the stereo, was sitting on a couch 12 feet away and was uninjured. Ensley said he did not know who loaned Belkins the equipment. About 90 minutes earlier Saturday evening, a pipe bomb exploded on the roof of a Kmart store. Police released no additional information on the store blast, and all calls to Kmart offices went unanswered Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Precede VATICAN CITY
Gorbachev: `New Ideas' Have Emerged To Avoid War In Gulf
With AM-Summit-Gorbachev's Troubles, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Gorbachev comments on the gulf crisis, details. Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Sunday he is convinced there is a peaceful way out of the Persian Gulf crisis and that ``new ideas'' have emerged to avert war. Efforts for a political solution in the gulf figured prominently in Gorbachev's brief stay in Rome and his talks with Pope John Paul II, who said he was praying the world will be spared the ``horrors'' of a military conflict. Gorbachev renewed his invitation to the Polish-born pope, first made during their historic talks a year ago, for a papal visit to the Soviet Union. The pope later told reporters he hoped to go but would not commit himself to a date. ``The right moment will come,'' said John Paul, whose efforts for religious freedom contributed to the revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe. Vatican officials said the trip could not take place before 1992, stressing that the Vatican first needs to assess the number of faithful, priests and bishops and the overall state of the church in the Soviet Union. For Gorbachev, who was greeted by large and friendly crowds, his brief stop gave him a respite from his political and economic troubles at home. He signed a 20-year friendship treaty with Italy which includes a non-aggression clause, won commitments of nearly $5 billion over five years in support for the Soviet economy, and received a $450,000 human rights prize from an Italian foundation backed by a mineral water company. Much of his day was spent in talks on the crisis caused by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. After signing the friendship treaty at the Quirinal presidential palace, Gorbachev said it was a ``test'' for the international community to try to resolve the gulf crisis peacefully. ``I am convinced that we will succeed in finding a way out of this deep crisis,'' he said, speaking in Russian which was translated into Italian. ``There are new ideas which need to be examined. We are headed to the quest of a solution to this grave crisis which involves everyone.'' Gorbachev did not elaborate on the new ideas. His spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, said they were discussed in the private talks between Gorbachev and Premier Giulio Andreotti. The Soviet spokesman said Gorbachev and the pope stressed the need for U.N. involvement and the importance of the role played by Arab countries. Ignatenko said Gorbachev would discuss the ideas with President Bush, German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, French President Francois Mitterrand and other leaders during the East-West summit opening Monday in Paris. The spokesman said Gorbachev stressed that the United Nations ``still has the chance to increase the pressure on Saddam Hussein.'' Andreotti's spokesman, Pio Mastrobouoni, said the two leaders agreed that efforts to avoid a military conflict in the gulf must continue. ``One cannot be resigned to the need to resort to force unless absolutely necessary,'' he quoted Andreotti as saying. Gorbachev termed his talks with the pope ``very satisfying'' and said they discussed ``the most important problems in Europe and the world.'' In its communique, the Vatican said the talks were ``open and very friendly,'' adding that it viewed the audience as a continuation of the dialogue started during Gorbachev's first visit on Dec. 1, 1989. Those historic talks paved the way for the establishment of official Moscow-Vatican ties in March and the exchange of ambassadors. Gorbachev kept his promise to the pope for enactment of a freedom of religion law which, among other things, legalized the long suppressed Ukrainian Catholic Church. The Ukranian issue had been a major impediment to a papal visit. Ignatenko quoted Gorbachev as saying his next meeting with John Paul would ``perhaps, or probably, be in the USSR.'' Gorbachev was accompanied to the Vatican by his wife Raisa, who wore a gray suit. For last year's visit, she wore a red dress, raising eyebrows here.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Suffers Mild Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Barney Frank was resting comfortably Sunday in an intensive care unit after suffering a mild heart attack while exercising at a health club, hospital officials said. The 50-year-old Massachusetts Democrat checked himself into Beth Israel Hospital on Saturday night complaining of chest pains. An examination showed blockage of a coronary artery and an angioplasty was performed, the hospital said. ``I'm pleased to say treatment seems to be working,'' said Dr. William Grossman, a Beth Israel cardiologist. ``He has no other medical problems.'' Frank, who was easily re-elected this month to a sixth term, was being treated in the hospital's intensive care unit. Dorothy Reichard, a Frank aide, said Saturday he ``had been working out, he had been in the gym and started to feel some chest pain and decided to go to the hospital.'' National attention focused on Frank last summer when the House reprimanded him for actions stemming from his relationship with a male prostitute.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Gets A Week Vacation After 21 Hours In Water
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: British sailor Chris Boorman gained a week's holiday with his family in England after surviving 21 hours bobbing in the Persian Gulf earlier this week, a Royal Navy spokesman said Sunday. ``We've sent him for about a week. We want him to have a quiet leave without undue pressure,'' said spokesman Anton Hanney. He did not give Boorman's hometown. He described Boorman's physical and mental condition as very good after the incident on Nov. 12, in which the sailor fell overboard from the HMS Cattistock, one of the Royal Navy's Armilla Patrol ships deployed in the standoff against Iraq. Boorman, a petty officer, described his ordeal as a ``freak accident.'' He managed to tread water, swim and float on his back for 21 hours. For 18 of them, his companions thought he was ashore. The minute they realized he was missing, Royal Navy warships and six helicopters launched a search operation in the waters. It was shortly after that the USS Blue Ridge, command and control vessel of the U.S. armada, found him 50 miles southwest of Dubai's Jebel Ali late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: India Yet To Formally Apply For IMF Gulf Hardship Loan
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund has offered India a $400 to $450 million loan to compensate for hardship suffered under U.N. sanctions against Iraq. India said Sunday it hadn't decided whether to accept. ``We are undecided, it is too early to say yes or no'' said Finance Secretary Bimal Jalan. The loan was approved Friday by the Washington-based world body, but it was not reported in the India media. India had pleaded with the IMF in September to modify terms of assistance to countries under the Compensatory and Contingency Financing Facility to inlcude hardships faced by the oil crisis. ``The IMF accepted our argument and saw the logic in it,'' Jamal said. India increased the price of gasoline and other petroleum products by 25 percent on Oct. 10. Two days earlier, the government announced a fuel cut by 15 percent and warned of other harsh measures to adjust to the gulf crisis. The government had calculated that the gulf crisis would cost India $2.4 billion in higher fuel bills over the next 12 months, based on an average of $25 per barrel. But the price of oil has hovored near $40 a barrel, upsetting India's crisis planning.

DOC.HEAD: Former Utah Governor Herbert Maw Dies At Age 97
DOC.TEXT: Herbert B. Maw, who served two terms as governor in the 1940s, died Saturday. He was 97. He died in a Salt Lake City nursing home of old age, said his son, Warren Maw. Maw was born March 11, 1893, in Ogden, the Territory of Deseret, three years before Utah became a state. He received a law degree from the University of Utah in 1916 and a doctorate from Northwestern University in 1927. During World War I Maw served as a pilot and was among the Army's first Mormon chaplains. A Democrat, he was elected governor in 1940 and served two terms. At age 93, Maw was still practicing law. In an interview in 1984 he said he still walked three miles a day, a habit from the days when he couldn't afford a trolley ride. He is survied by two sons and two daughters, 19 grandchildren and 31 great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Oscar-Winning Screenwriter Maurice Richlin Dead at 70
DOC.TEXT: Maurice N. Richlin, an Oscar-winning screenwriter of ``Pillow Talk'' who helped create the clumsy Inspector Clouseau in ``The Pink Panther,'' has died of cancer. He was 70. Richlin died Tuesday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center, nursing supervisor Ruth Brymer said over the weekend. Richlin and his writing partner, Stanley Shapiro, won an Academy Award for the 1959 romantic comedy ``Pillow Talk,'' which starred Rock Hudson and Doris Day. That same year the duo had a second nomination in the same category, best story written for the screen, for ``Operation Petticoat,'' starring Cary Grant and Tony Curtis. With Blake Edwards, Richlin wrote ``The Pink Panther,'' the 1963 comedy featuring Peter Sellers as a bumbling French detective. Richlin, a native of Omaha, Neb., attended the University of Missouri and served in the Army during World War II. After the war he moved to Los Angeles, where he worked as a reporter for the Los Angeles Times and the Hollywood Citizen News. Before taking up screenwriting, he turned his talents to radio, writing scripts for such popular series as ``Burns and Allen,'' ``The Edgar Bergen Show'' and ``The Amos and Andy Show.'' Richlin is survived by his wife, Louise, six children and three grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Cold In East, Stormy In Alaska
DOC.TEXT: A storm threatened parts of Alaska on Sunday with a possibility of a blizzard, and a cold front chilled the East Coast as far south as North Carolina. Alaska's storm was moving inland Sunday from the northern Bering Sea. Winter storm watches were in effect through Monday for the northern Seward Peninsula and the lower Kobuk Valley, along the Arctic Coast and for the lower Yukon Valley. Blizzard conditions were possible along the coast. A cold front prevailed from Maine to North Carolina, bringing in brisk northwesterly wind. Gale warnings were posted along the coast of Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Maryland, Delaware, Virginia and northern North Carolina. Afternoon temperatures ranged from the 50s over the Carolinas to the 30s across much of the northern Atlantic Coast region. A frost warning was posted overnight into Monday morning for the midlands of South Carolina, with frost and freeze warnings for the mountains and foothills. Elsewhere, a weak upper-level weather disturbance produced a few light showers over Missouri during the afternoon, and showers associated with a cold front over the Northwest spread over southwestern Oregon and northwestern California. Above the Arctic Circle, Sunday's sunset was the last glimpse of the sun for 65 days. The next sunrise will be 1:05 p.m. AST on Jan. 23, according to the National Weather Service. Sunday morning's low for the Lower 48 states was 18 at Elkins, W.Va.

DOC.HEAD: Singer David Crosby Breaks Bones in Motorcycle Spill
DOC.TEXT: Rock musician David Crosby suffered broken bones in a weekend motorcycle spill and was hospitalized in stable condition Sunday, officials said. Crosby's left leg, left ankle and left shoulder were broken but he was doing well at Cedars Sinai Medical Center, said hospital spokesman Ron Wise. Crosby is a founding member of the group Crosby, Stills & Nash, which later became Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young. The 49-year-old Crosby went down on a curve while riding through the Los Angeles suburb of Encino on Saturday and skidded about 40 feet, said police Officer Leona Thomas. The motorcycle was apparently speeding on the 25 mph road, she said ``He says his throttle got stuck,'' Thomas said. Crosby was not wearing a helmet, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Sultan of Oman Forms Council, Promises More Democracy
DOC.TEXT: The sultan of Oman marked his 20th year in power Sunday by offering to create a council of representatives to give residents of this desert monarchy more say in government. Sultan Qaboos became the latest Arab monarch to indicate a willingness to allow greater democracy. Saudi Arabia and Kuwait's government-in-exile earlier made such offers. The sultan, in a speech before thousands of Omanis, said the council, known as the Majlis al-Shura, would be created within a year and would be made up of representatives from the country's 42 provinces. He did not say whether they would be elected or appointed. The Majlis al-Shura is described in the Koran, Islam's holy book, as a consultative council to help rulers manage affairs of state. Normally its members are society elders chosen by the ruler. Oman, a nation of 1.5 million, already has a State Consultative Council whose 55 members were chosen by the sultan. Qaboos implied the two bodies would exist side by side as he did not say the existing council would disappear. ``This is another step on the road of participation that serves the aspirations of the citizens,'' he said. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait has made the gulf sheikdoms uneasy about maintaining their hold on power and exposed them to Western scrutiny, and some have made concessions to their populations. In neighboring Saudi Arabia, King Fahd announced Nov. 8 that a consultative council would be formed, a move Saudi kings have discussed periodically for decades but never acted on. In October, exiled Kuwaiti leaders met in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, and told politicicians that a rebuilt Kuwait would be more democratic. In Oman and Saudi Arabia, the monarch is the center of the power, serving as his own prime minister. The two leaders observe the Islamic tradition of a weekly ``majlis,'' an open meeting at which the ruler and princes listen to petitions from their citizens. The United Arab Emirates and Qatar also have Shura Councils. Among the Islamic countries on the Arabian Peninsula, only Kuwait had a Western-style elected parliament, although it had been dissolved at the time of the invasion of Kuwait. The sultan's speech came during a weeklong celebration of his 20 years in power and his 50th birthday. Nightly fireworks light up the skies while floats carrying musicians and Arabian tableaux drift through the streets. On Sunday, British-made attack planes zoomed over a military parade at Maidan al-Fateh Stadium. About 1,000 Dhofar tribesmen, bare-chested and wearing indigo loincloths, performed acrobatic feats for the king, tossing their swords 30 feet into the air. Speaking after the parade, Qaboos called for Iraq to leave Kuwait but stressed his wish for a peaceful settlement. As part of an economic reform package, Qaboos offered incentives for small businesses and said this oil-producing country needed to diversify its economy. Like the other gulf nations, Oman relies heavily on an expatriate workforce, one third of the country's population, according to Western diplomats. Most foreign workers are from the Indian subcontinent.

DOC.HEAD: Traffic Official Owes $1,967 on Tickets And Refuses To Pay
DOC.TEXT: A former state senator who now is assistant budget director of Philadelphia Traffic Court owes $1,967 in traffic fines and says he has no intention of paying. ``Why ... should I pay,'' T. Milton Street told The Philadelphia Inquirer, using an expletive to emphasize his resolve. ``My rights have been violated. They violate people's rights (at Traffic Court) every day.'' Besides, he said: ``I don't have any money.'' The newspaper dug up 19 tickets dating from 1984 for violations ranging from driving without a license to driving unregistered and uninspected vehicles, including a taxicab. The newspaper reported Saturday that the violations also include running a stop sign, abandoning a vehicle and reckless driving. Street was hired by Traffic Court President Judge George Twardy last year at an annual salary of $30,000. ``Holy cripes!'' Twardy said when the newspaper informed him of Street's tickets. ``That's a disgrace.'' The judge said he will issue an order Monday that all court employees clear up ticket problems or risk disciplinary action. Street seemed unconcerned. ``Think I'm the only one here got tickets? A lot of people here got tickets,'' he said. Street contended the court violated drivers' rights by requiring them to post collateral in the amount of their fines before an appeal hearing. ``I'm not paying for a hearing,'' he said. Street said he saw no contradiction in his situation with the court. ``I'm the most capable person in the city that's available to do this job,'' he said. ``I'm better than anybody else.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Veterans Build Clinic in Town Destroyed by U.S. Bombs
DOC.TEXT: Nine U.S. veterans of the Vietnam war have returned to an old battlefield to rebuild a clinic destroyed by American bombs, the official Vietnam News Agency reported Sunday. The veterans worked with local residents to erect a 10-room clinic at Yen Vien, about six miles east of Hanoi, the national capital, the report monitored in Bangkok said. The Veterans Vietnam Restoration Project, based in Garberville, Calif., put up the $30,000 construction cost. The North Country Clinic of Arcata, Calif., is providing medicine and other supplies. The clinic opened Oct. 20 to serve more than 30,000 residents of Yen Vien and seven surrounding villages, the agency reported. Yen Vien was ``razed by U.S. carpet bombing'' ordered by President Nixon in December 1972 to pressure the Communists into a peace agreement. The bombing of the Hanoi and Haiphong harbor areas became known as the Christmas bombings. The veterans group was led by John Baca, 41, who won the Medal of Honor for saving his squadron from a 1968 grenade attack by a North Vietnamese soldier. Baca covered the grenade with his helmet and lay on top of it. He was severely wounded. Art James, 41, was an infantryman in Baca's squad in the 1st Air Cavalry who suffered shrapnel wounds in that explosion. James was among the veterans rebuilding the clinic in Yen Vien. James said he had found the Vietnamese a forgiving people. ``Forgiveness is part of a message I need when I go back to America,'' he said. Some of the veterans see the project as a way to influence Washington to end its economic embargo and normalize relations with Vietnam, said Cherie Rankin, a 44-year-old psychotherapist from Norwood, Mass., who was a Red Cross worker in Vietnam in 1970-71. ``The other reason was to try to do something constructive in a country where I was involved in doing something destructive,'' she said. John Burns, 43, said he returned ``to find some peace of mind,'' and because ``we learned nothing about Vietnam before, except for what our government told us.'' ``I wanted very much to come back and learn about Vietnam and find the truth about the people ... and this has been the most incredible experience of my life,'' he was quoted as saying. Burns served in Vietnam in 1967-69 with the 45th Combat Engineer Battalion attached to the 1st Air Calvary. The report said it was the third clinic built by the Veterans Vietnam Restoration Project. Two were constructed last year, at Vung Tau, 60 miles southwest of Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, and at Vinh, in central Vietnam. The U.S. government has eased restrictions on the activities of American humanitarian groups in Vietnam since August 1987, in return for Vietnamese cooperation in accounting for missing American soldiers. Many U.S. veterans have returned in recent years to visit old battlefields and see the country under Communist rule. For the first time, a group of Vietnamese army veterans visited the United States this year to share experiences with U.S. veterans.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega: King Hussein to Meet President Bush in Paris
DOC.TEXT: Former Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega, who met with King Hussein on Sunday, said the monarch planned to meet President Bush in Paris to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. Bush arrived in Paris on Sunday to address an extraordinary 34-nation summit that will start Monday. ``They must look for a solution through dialogue and negotiations,'' Ortega said of the two leaders. Jordanian Information Minister Ibrahim Izzeddine refused to confirm the report. Hussein's other aides were not immediately available for comment. Hussein, whose country is heavily reliant on Iraq and has been hurt by the U.N. economic sanctions, has been a self-appointed mediator for the crisis. He met with Bush several days after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2., but Bush was not receptive of Hussein's call for foreign troops to stay out of the region and allow Arab leaders to settle the dispute. Ortega arrived in Amman on Saturday after a four-day visit to Baghdad, where he met President Saddam Hussein. Ortega said he was going home Monday to Nicaragua, where he leads the leftist opposition Sandinista National Liberation Front.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says Almost 240 POWs Due Home This Week
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is sending 239 Iranian prisoners of war back home by Wednesday as the two nations resume their exchange of POWs, Iran's official news agency reported Sunday. The Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Iran is ready to release 100 Iraqi prisoners of war per day as a sign of goodwill. Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati announced Saturday after returning from a two-day trip to Baghdad that the exchange of prisoners from the 1980-88 war was resuming. Velayati was the highest-ranking Iranian to visit Baghdad since Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution. Up to 100,000 prisoners of war have yet to be repatriated. An exchange started in August after President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accepted Iran's conditions for establishing a formal peace. He was apparently seeking peace on his eastern border while building up his forces in the west in the confrontation over his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq suspended the exchanges in September without explanation.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Trad E. Nazer...,' to CORRECT that driver was nephew, sted son, of consul-general.
DOC.TEXT: The nephew of Saudi Arabia's consul general here surrendered to authorities following a hit-and-run accident that killed a 73-year-old woman, police said Sunday. The driver, Trad E. Nazer, 20, was accompanied by his uncle, consul-general Hassan Nazer, when he turned himself in shortly after the accident late Friday, said Sgt. Jim Boudreau. He was booked on vehicular manslaughter charges and released on $30,000 bail soon after the accident Boudreau said. Diplomatic immunity would not apply in this case, the officer said. The woman was crossing a street when Nazer's car struck her, police said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Says Farm Subsidies Agreement Is Distant
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter said Sunday that prospects for an international agreement on reduced agricultural subsidies are bleak. The dispute over farm subsidies, pitting the United States against France and Germany, is threatening to jeopardize a four-year effort to reform the global trading system. Speaking of an agreement on subsidies, Yeutter told Swedish national television: ``The chances of success are very, very slim. We hope that something will change in the next couple of weeks to alter that assessment.'' He spent the last week meeting with European officials to seek a farm subsidies agreement. Officials had hoped to resolve the issue in time for global trade talks scheduled to open in Brussels, Belgium, on Dec. 3. The United States and other big farm exporters, like Argentina, want the agriculture agreement to include 75 percent cuts in subsidies and 90 percent cuts in customs tariffs. The 12-member European Community, including France and Germany, has offered to agree to a 30 percent cut in farm subsidies over 10 years. Sweden and other European countries that are not members of the EC have agreed to subsidy cuts of up to 50 percent. The global trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where they were launched in 1986, involve 105 nations. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills warned Thursday that a failure of the trade talks in Belgium would increase tensions among trading partners and could frustrate international cooperation on issues ranging from the gulf crisis to the environment. The Bush administration has a lot riding on the trade agreement. U.S. officials believe that removing trade barriers is the best hope for lowering huge U.S. trade deficits by expanding overseas sales. Farmers in Europe have staged noisy protests in recent weeks to assure their governments do not buckle under to pressure to lower farm subsidies.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Set Off Bombs as Throng Cheers the Emperor
DOC.TEXT: More than 100,000 people thronged to the Imperial Palace on Sunday to cheer newly enthroned Emperor Akihito, but radicals set off several bombs near a shrine he is to visit. Akihito, Empress Michiko and other royal family members, protected by bulletproof glass, came out onto the palace balcony eight times during the day to greet the well-wishers, which the Imperial Household Agency numbered at 109,800. Loud shouts of ``Long live the emperor!'' rang through the palace courtyard as he finished his short statement giving thanks to the crowds. Akihito became emperor immediately after his father, Emperor Hirohito, died in January 1989. His formal enthronement Nov. 12 followed a mourning period. Enthronement-related ceremonies are to continue into December. At least four explosions occurred Sunday near the Grand Shrines of Ise, 180 miles southwest of Tokyo, which Akihito is to visit next week, said an official of Mie Prefectural Police who spoke on condition of anonymity. No injuries or major damage were reported in the explosions, two of which occurred at the Ujiyamada railway station and two along a railway track near the station. The emperor and empress are to use the railroad when they travel to Ise to pray to the sun goddess on Nov. 27-28. Japan's line of emperors is said to have descended from the sun goddess Amaterasu. Radicals claimed responsibility for dozens of explosions and fires in Tokyo during Akihito's enthronement. None caused serious injuries. The radicals oppose the monarchy as a remnant of Japan's prewar imperialism.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Beatle's Birth Certificate Sold for $18,000 at Auction
DOC.TEXT: A 26-year-old Beatles fan who got interested in the group almost a decade after it broke up paid $18,000 Sunday for what's said to be Paul McCartney's birth certificate. ``I'm just a Beatles freak and I had to have it,'' said Brian Taylor of Washington, D.C. ``It's a hobby that's gone a little too far.'' After paying Simpson's auction house a 10 percent fee and Texas's 8.25 percent sales tax, Taylor will pay $21,285 for the document. The auction house said it had determined the document is authentic. It took less than a minute for Taylor to outbid his two competitors, one at Simpson's and one bidding by telephone. The birth certificate took a long and winding road from Liverpool to Houston via the singer's stepmother, Angela Williams, who sold it to an American investor for an unknown amount. The certificate shows that on June 18, 1942, at 107 Rice Lane, James Paul McCartney was born to James McCartney, a ``centre lathe turner (aircraft factory),'' and Mary Patricia McCartney, of 10 Sunbury Road, Liverpool, England. Taylor, a student of urban planning at Virginia Commonwealth University, in Richmond, said he got interested in the Beatles when he was about 13 years old. He has all their records, including some rare recordings, he said. Taylor said he would ``show it all my friends,'' then keep the document in a safe deposit box. He refused to discuss the source of his money, but said, ``I had a paper route as a kid.'' If the pop star wants his birth certificate back, he should bring his checkbook, Taylor said. ``Sure, I'll sell it to him,'' he said. ``I would have to talk about (the price) to Mr. McCartney himself.''

DOC.HEAD: Socialist-Backed Candidate Elected Governor of Okinawa
DOC.TEXT: A Socialist-backed candidate who wants the United States to abandon its military bases on Okinawa was elected governor of the island prefecture Sunday. Masahide Ota, 65, backed by the Socialists, Communists and other opposition parties, defeated Junji Nishime, a conservative who has been governor of Okinawa for 12 years. In nearly compete returns, Ota had 330,924 votes to Nishime's 300,739. Nishime, 69, was backed by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Liberal Democratic Party and the moderate opposition Democratic Socialist Party. His third four-year term expires Dec. 9. Okinawa, site of some of the bloodiest fighting in World War II, is host to 35,000 of the 64,000 U.S. troops based in Japan. Okinawa is the southernmost major island of Japan, about 900 miles southwest of Tokyo. In a poll earlier this year by the prime minister's office, about 60 percent of Okinawans said they felt the U.S. bases were unnecessary or dangerous for Japanese security. Another 29 percent supported the bases. Ota, a professor of sociology at Ryukyu University in Okinawa, campaigned against the bases. He also opposed Kaifu's proposal to send Japanese soldiers to the Persian Gulf where they would have non-combat roles in the international force opposing Iraq. Kaifu's proposal died in Parliament because of strong objections by the opposition. The election committee said an estimated 75.3 percent of the 830,000 eligible voters turned out, compared with 74.1 percent in the last election in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Agency Won't Send Women To Inspect Iranian Grain Ships
DOC.TEXT: Female grain inspectors will no longer board Iranian ships here after the crew of one vessel refused to allow an Agriculture Canada official on board without a veil. A federal official said recently that the action was the only solution to a sensitive cultural and religious issue. But a woman's organization decried the policy as reinforcing bias against women. ``The Canadian position when dealing with a country like Iran, which has certain cultural-religious practices, is that we should be as non-confrontational as much as possible,'' said Kingsley Chong, Agriculture Canada district manager. ``Whenever there is an Iranian ship in port, operational requirements permitting, then we will avoid sending women aboard.'' The policy arose after an incident on Oct. 16 when two Canadian inspectors tried to board the Iran Jamal, an Iranian ship docked at a British Columbian port. One of the inspectors was a woman. The crew barred her from boarding until she put on a veil. ``Here we have a case where Canadian women are being forced into being culturally sensitive by being barred from doing their job,'' said Sunera Thobani of the Vancouver Status of Women committee. ``It is clearly a case of discrimination against women.'' Canada shipped $256 million worth of grain to Iran in 1989, about 9 percent of all Canadian grain shipments last year.

DOC.HEAD: NOW Board Condemns Military Buildup in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The National Organization For Women on Sunday condemned the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. The national board of NOW, which held policy meetings in Boston over the weekend, adopted a resolution calling on Congress to act ``assertively'' to encourage withdrawal of troops from the gulf, according to NOW spokeswoman Ellen Zucker. The statement contends both Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are ``despotic, clan-run monarchies'' that ``systematically oppress women, denying them the basic human right of self determination, freedom of speech, association, transportation and dress.'' ``Although NOW does not support the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, we are appalled at the possibility that lives should be lost to defend the oppressive regimes of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia,'' the resolution said. NOW urged the administration and Congress to develop a national energy policy that reduces American reliance on oil.

DOC.HEAD: Councilman Killed, Congressman Wounded in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Assassins killed a city councilman and wounded a governing party congressman in a northern city Sunday, police said. Unidentified gunmen in Apartado opened fire on Jesus Maria Velasquez, a councilman for the city, and Elkin Garcia Castrillon, a congressman and member of the Liberal Party, according to a police statement. Velasquez was killed immediately. Garcia was being treated for a slight bullet wound in a hospital in Apartado, near the border with Panama. The two men were meeting together in the city when the attack occurred. The police statement gave no other details. Massacres and other political violence have plagued Apartado and the surrounding region, where both leftist guerrillas and right-wing death squads are active.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rejects CNN Bid To Broadcast Noriega Tapes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with comments from Noriega's attorney, inserts new grafs 12-13: Noriega's defense ....
