DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court refused by a 7-2 vote Sunday to give Cable News Network permission to broadcast tape recordings of conversations between Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega and his lawyers. The court rejected an emergency request by CNN that was aimed at lifting a federal judge's order forbidding the broadcasts until he could determine what the tapes disclose. The emergency request had called the Nov. 8 order by U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler in Miami an unconstitutional ``prior restraint'' of free speech. But only two justices - Thurgood Marshall and Sandra Day O'Connor - agreed with that assessment. Voting against CNN were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and David H. Souter. The Justice Department had joined with Noriega's lawyers in opposing the request. In addition to the emergency request, the court also turned down a formal appeal filed by the cable network, in a one-sentence order. CNN President Tom Johnson called the court's decision ``a loss of a battle in a continuing war against censorship.'' Johnson said the network would immediately turn the tapes in its possession over to Judge Hoeveler. He said CNN is ``confident that after he reviews them he will decide on the merits to deny the prior restraint.'' ``CNN is committed to establishing its full freedom to telecast newsworthy information to the American people and it will pursue this case vigorously in order to do so,'' Johnson said. Floyd Abrams, CNN's attorney in the case, said the court's decison ``has left an opening through which defense lawyers and prosecutors may try to muzzle news articles.'' ``The refusal of the court to hear the case does seem to countenance brief prior restraints of a few days duration based on almost no showing of need at all by the courts,'' Abrams said. Noriega's defense attorney, Jon May, said CNN had opened a ``Pandora's box'' with its First Amendment challenge. ``We think its a correct ruling,'' May said. ``This is a case of the messenger shooting itself. To whatever extent the media may complain this is a significant adverse decision, CNN has only itself to blame.'' In a dissenting opinion for himself and O'Connor, Marshall said ``this case is of extraordinary consequence for freedom of the press.'' ``Our precedents make unmistakably clear that any prior restraint of expression comes to this court bearing a heavy presumption against its constitutional validity and that the proponent of this drastic remedy carries a heavy burden of showing justification for its imposition,'' Marshall said. ``I do not see how the prior restraint imposed in this case can be reconciled with these teachings,'' Marshall said. ``Even more fundamentally, if the lower courts in this case are correct in their remarkable conclusion that publication can be automatically restrained pending application of the demanding test established by (a 1976 decision that severely limited the power of judges to impose such restraints) then I think it is imperative that we re-examine the premises and operation of (that decision).'' Jane Kirtley, executive director Reporter's Committee for Freedom of the Press, said she was ``stunned'' by the decision, which she called ``truly unprecedented.'' ``The fact that the court would be willing to tolerate a prior restraint in these circumstances signals a new era in First Amendment jurisprudence,'' Kirtley said. ``It will have a far-reaching impact going beyond this case extending to many cases in state and federal courts around the country. Bruce Sanford, an attorney for the Society of Professional Journalists, said the court's decision is ``troublesome because it seems inconceivable that Noriega's counsel would ever be able to prove that his right to a fair trial was in jeopardy because of the CNN tapes.'' Walt Wurfel, a spokesman for the National Association of Broadcasters, said his group was ``very disappointed'' with the court's decision. ``We view the lower court's order as prior restraint,'' he said. The Bush administration Saturday had urged the high court to leave intact Hoeveler's order. Solicitor General Kenneth Starr, the government's top-ranking courtroom lawyer, argued in written briefs that the restraining order was justified to give the judge time to determine whether seven tapes in CNN's possession might interfere with Noriega's ability to receive a fair trial. Noriega, who is awaiting trial on charges of taking $4.6 million in payoffs to protect cocaine trade through Panama, is being held in a federal prison near Miami. Federal prison authorities monitor and tape record all inmates' telephone conversations except those between an inmates and their defense teams. But the CNN tape recordings reportedly contain some conversations between the deposed Panamanian leader and his defense lawyers. Sunday's high court order, issued without any explanatory opinion, does not necessarily preclude the possibility that some day the court will rule that Hoeveler's order did violate CNN's free-speech rights. The court conceivably could have refused to help CNN because of some procedural reason. The cable network might carry its legal battle back to the court at some later date. But meanwhile, CNN is under court order not to broadcast those portions of its tapes divulging Noriega's conversations with his lawyers. If those conversations are broadcast, CNN could be cited with contempt of court and fined heavily. The federal government lost a much-publicized battle over a prior restraint in 1971 when the Supreme Court allowed The New York Times and The Washington Post to publish the so-called Pentagon papers detailing American involvement in Vietnam. In a key 1976 decision stemming from pretrial publicity in a Nebraska murder case, the court ruled that forbidding the news media from publishing or broadcasting information in its possession almost never can be justified. The court in that decision called such prior restraints - sometimes referred to as ``gag orders'' - the ``least tolerable'' measures of assuring fair trials. In seeking the prior restraint against CNN, Noriega's lawyers argued that broadcasting the tapes would poison their client's fair-trial rights in two ways: through pretrial publicity and by compromising his relationship with his lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Two Police Killed by Bomb in Basque Region
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden by Basque terrorists in a parked van exploded Sunday as police drove by, authorities said. Two officers were reported killed and two wounded. The van was parked on a highway near Santurce, seven miles north of the northern industrial city of Bilbao, said a police official, who was not identified under standing rules. The bomb was set off by remote control. Police blamed the radical separatist group ETA, which has carried out similar attacks in the past, the official said. ETA, the Basque language acronym for Basque Homeland and Liberty, has claimed responsibility for killing more than 600 people since 1968, including 19 this year. The group seeks independence for the three-province Basque country of northeastern Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Gather At Monument To Franco
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Spaniards sang old fascist songs and railed against democracy Sunday at a statue of Gen. Francisco Franco on the 15th anniversary of the dictator's death. The crowd of about 5,000 included Fascists, neo-Nazis, nostalgic middle-aged adults, white-haired Spanish Civil War veterans, and many clean-cut teen-agers too young to remember Franco's 36 years in power. Franco died at 83 on Nov. 20, 1975. He became head of state following the victory of his Nationalist rebel army in the 1936-39 civil war. His daughter, Carmen Franco Polo, attended the hourlong rally, as did Blas Pinar, the leader of the Francoist National Front party. The party has no representation in parliament. A woman opened the rally by reading a poem of lament: ``Spain, poor Spain. You were so beautiful. Now you're degraded. ... Be patient, you will be as you were before - clean, saintly and purified. The dirty sinners will be plucked out.'' A Roman Catholic priest prayed for those who ``fell for the fatherland'' during the Civil War. The rally closed with stiff-arm salutes and the singing of the Spanish fascist battle hymn, ``Face to the Sun.'' In past anniversaries, youths have smashed car windows and set trash barrels on fire, but police said there was no violence at this year's event. The ralliers expressed nostalgia for Franco's repressive Spain, where leftists and other non-conformists had no place. They said Franco did better than later leaders at controlling crime, terrorism and unemployment. Since Franco's death, Spain has moved gradually into the European cultural and economic mainstream. A Socialist, Felipe Gonzalez, has been prime minister since 1982. Supporters of Jean-Marie Le Pen's National Front party, the ultraconservative party in France, attended the rally in combat fatigues.

DOC.HEAD: Four Explosions Shake Filipino Justice Secretary's Home
DOC.TEXT: Four explosions rocked the home of Justice Secretary Franklin Drilon early Monday, but the official and his family were not injured, police said. The explosions occurred at 4:05 a.m. at Drilon's home in the fashionable Greenhills district of suburban San Juan, less than one mile from Camp Crame, headquarters of the national police. The blasts shattered widows and damaged the roof but caused no injuries, police said. There was no claim of responsibility. Drilon's department supervises the National Bureau of Investigation and other offices involved in criminal investigations. He also serves as chairman of the Cabinet Security Committee, which advises President Corazon Aquino on security.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Calls Iraqi Hostage Offer `Cynical Manipulation'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's offer to free all foreign hostages by March 25 is ``just further cynical manipulation of innocent people's lives,'' U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Sunday. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``never should have taken them in the first place,'' Baker said. ``He has it in his power to release them immediately, as the United Nations and indeed the international community are demanding, and I think this is just further cynical manipulation of innocent people's lives.'' Baker later met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze for two hours in anticipation of a meeting Monday between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Both officials declined afterward to say whether the Soviet Union would back a U.S.-proposed resolution in the U.N. Security Council authorizing the use of force against Iraq. ``I cannot say that we have reached any decisions,'' Shevardnadze said. ``Tomorrow these discussions will continue at a presidential level. It's not so simple that we can just come out and announce something.'' Baker told reporters after the meeting to ``stay tuned'' and indicated an announcement could come Monday night. ``I have pointed out before the importance of maintaining to the extent we can a common approach and a common understanding with respect to this problem, and we're working on that,'' he said. Baker commented on the Iraqi announcement just before meeting British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, one of series of talks on the eve of a three-day European summit. Baker was seeking support for the U.S. stance against Hussein. After his talks with Baker, Hurd said Saddam's offer was just a ``further demonstration of the policy of the human shield,'' in which Iraq has placed hostages in strategic places to try to discourage an attack. ``Why doesn't he let them go this week?'' Hurd said of Saddam and the hostages. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the announcement appeared deliberately timed by Saddam as an effort to divert attention from President Bush's planned Thanksgiving visit with troops in the Persian Gulf region. ``He (Saddam) does it all the time,'' Fitzwater said, referring to other earlier gestures by Saddam in freeing foreigners. ``We want all the hostages released.'' Earlier, Baker said the United States was not sure whether Iraq is armed with highly accurate Soviet-made SS-12 missiles capable of carrying chemical warheads. ``We would be concerned about that if it is confirmed,'' Baker told reporters after talks with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. ``As of yet, it has not been confirmed. It is something we are inquiring into,'' Baker said. The Washington Post reported Friday that a Western diplomat in Baghdad reported that the Soviets had given Iraq some of the SS-12 medium-range missiles. The diplomat said he did not know how many missiles were sent or when they were sent. Baker also discussed a possible U.N. resolution with the foreign ministers of Romania and Finland, both current members of the Security Council.

DOC.HEAD: Arms Cuts Will Erase European Fear of Surprise Attack
DOC.TEXT: A landmark arms treaty cutting non-nuclear forces in Europe is far from the final step in disarmament, but it offers one over arching reward: the end to fear of a massive surprise ground attack. It also may open the way for the eventual elimination of U.S. and Soviet nuclear weapons from Europe, some analysts believe, although that issue is strongly debated. The Conventional Forces in Europe, or CFE, treaty scheduled to be signed Monday in Paris alters the military balance in Europe mainly by erasing Moscow's ability to mass huge numbers of tanks and other heavy armor in central Europe. ``It is the definitive end of the surprise attack option'' for the Soviets, said Jonathan Dean, a former U.S. representative to East-West conventional arms negotiations. NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators in Vienna initialed the document on Sunday, ending 20 months of talks. From the start of the Cold War and the creation first of NATO in 1949 and then the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact alliance, the military landscape of Western Europe has been dominated by fear of a ``bolt from the blue'' communist-bloc ground assault. To eliminate that perceived threat, the CFE treaty - limiting the weapons of 22 countries and covering European territory from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains - requires the Soviets to drastically reduce their forces, including: - Tanks, from about 41,000 before the treaty negotiations began in 1989 to 13,150. Moscow already has reduced its tank holdings in the territory covered by the treaty to about 21,000, mainly by moving its best models east as replacements for older ones. The allowable number tanks for all of Eastern Europe will be 20,000. The United States and its NATO allies also will be allowed 20,000 tanks. That will require a cut of about 4,000 for NATO, although more than 1,000 of the top-of-the-line American M1-A1 tanks already are being moved from Europe to Saudi Arabia. - Armored combat vehicles, from the 32,300 now deployed by the Soviets to 30,000. NATO will not have to make any cuts in this category, which includes such war-fighting machinery as the U.S. Bradley Fighting Vehicle used to move infantry, protect maneuvering tanks and help consolidate gains in an offensive. - Artillery pieces, providing the essential firepower for a combat operation, from about 52,000 for the Soviets before the CFE negotiations began, to 13,175. The Soviets already have reduced to 18,300. NATO will stay at its current level of 18,500. Those three weapon categories - tanks, armored combat vehicles and artillery - are especially important to the military balance in Europe because they form the core of non-nuclear offensive capability for both the Soviets and NATO. Once the treaty is implemented, neither side will be able to marshal enough firepower within striking range of the other to launch a land invasion without setting off warning bells months, or even years, in advance, analysts say. Because most of the cuts will be made by the Soviets, no significant cost savings will be felt immediately by the NATO countries, according to the Institute for Defense and Disarmament Studies, a research group based at Brookline, Mass. The treaty does not include cuts in military personnel in Europe. A U.S.-Soviet agreement last February to limit each side to 195,000 foreign troops in central Europe, plus an additional 30,000 U.S. troops elsewhere in Europe, has been abandoned. The plan was overtaken by events, including the Soviets' declared intent to withdraw all their forces from central Europe within four years, the newly unified Germany's agreement to limit the size of its armed forces, and the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact as a coherent military force. Just last month Washington announced it would unilaterally withdraw 40,000 troops from Western Europe and close some of its bases there. Then on Nov. 8, President Bush ordered about 100,000 U.S. Army combat forces from Europe to Saudi Arabia as reinforcements against Iraq. That cuts U.S. Army strength in Europe by one-half, although it was presumed that some of those troops would later return to Europe. Most of the weapons to be withdrawn from Europe under the CFE treaty will be destroyed, although the treaty permits some to be converted to non-military or military support purposes. Neither the Soviets and their Warsaw Pact partners nor the United States and its NATO allies will be required to destroy any attack helicopters limited by the treaty. Those in excess of the 2,000 permitted by the treaty can be converted to noncombat roles. For other combat aircraft, the Soviets will be required to eliminate about one-third of their inventory in the area covered by the treaty. No cuts are required of the NATO countries because they already are well below the treaty limit of 6,800 combat aircraft.

DOC.BYLINE: FBI Arrests Two Trawler Crewmen In Shipboard Riot ^By JOHN ENDERS
DOC.TEXT: Two crewmen from a factory trawler were in federal custody Sunday facing assault charges after a shipboard riot over unpaid wages. The skipper and the chief engineer of the 205-foot Arctic Hero barricaded themselves inside the wheelhouse and engine room, respectively, after about seven of the 45 crew members rampaged through the vessel Friday, Coast Guard and FBI officials said. James R. Smith Jr., 26, and Reginald Collins, 28, both of Seattle, were being held in the Unalaska Department of Public Safety Jail in Unalaska, adjacent to Dutch Harbor in the Aleutian Islands, the FBI said. They were to be brought here for arraignment on the federal charges. The incident occurred in international waters in the Bering Sea, 100 miles west of Dutch Harbor, which is 800 miles southwest of Anchorage. Damage to the Seattle-based ship, which catches and processes fish, was estimated at $25,000. Three crew members were treated for minor injuries. The Coast Guard intercepted the vessel Friday after the captain called for help. The Arctic Hero was escorted to Dutch Harbor, where it was boarded Saturday by FBI, Coast Guard and National Marine Fisheries Service agents. Skipper Keith Dillon said the men rioted because the ship's owner, Palmco Pacific Corp. of Hawaii, failed to pay them on time, though he told them their paychecks were waiting on shore. Most of the crew stayed in their cabins during the disturbance. Dillon said the rioting crew members quit the trawler's fish processing line and, armed with clubs and fire axes, beat the chief engineer. They allegedly broke into a locker, drank some beer and took over parts of the vessel. The chief engineer kept control of the vessel by locking the engine room doors from the inside.

DOC.HEAD: Topol Stars in a Revival of `Fiddler on the Roof' on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: It has been more than 25 years since Zero Mostel first trudged across the stage of the Imperial Theater as Tevye the philosophical milkman in ``Fiddler on the Roof.'' There have been a lot of Tevyes since then, from Herschel Bernardi to Jan Peerce, but the role has been co-opted in recent years by Topol, the Israeli-born actor who starred in the London production of the musical as well as the movie version. Now, after a long national tour, Topol has arrived on Broadway where ``Fiddler'' opened Sunday at the Gershwin Theater. It's no surprise to report that star and show both hold up well. In fact, this is a glorious revival, with Topol delivering a genuine star turn. And the material hasn't grown old at all. ``Fiddler on the Roof'' was the last great musical in the Rodgers and Hammerstein tradition, a style R&H developed and perfected in the 1940s with such classic shows as ``Oklahoma!,'' ``Carousel'' and ``South Pacific.'' ``Fiddler,'' which originally opened in New York in September 1964, has that same extraordinary integration of story and song. There is not a wasted moment in the musical. Songs - music by Jerry Bock and lyrics by Sheldon Harnick - are used to explain character or advance plot. The story, which Joseph Stein artfully adapted from the stories of Sholom Aleichem, serves as a framework for those musical numbers. And everything was tied together perfectly by Jerome Robbins, whose original direction and choreography have been faithfully reproduced here by Ruth Mitchell and Sammy Dallas Bayes. There quite simply isn't a better opening scene in the American musical theater. In that one song, ``Tradition,'' the musical's underlying theme, the ties that bind together the small Jewish community in the turn-of-the-century Russian village of Anatevka, are brilliantly stated. The story of how those ties start to unravel, torn apart by personal, social and political upheavals, are brilliantly delineated by Bock, Harnick, Stein and especially Robbins. Topol's Tevye is more aristocratic than Mostel's milkman. He has a commanding voice, full and deep, and he moves with an authority that makes the eventual destruction of his world and the dispersal of his family especially poignant. Yet Topol doesn't miss a moment of the show's humor, never forgetting the man's indecisiveness, whether he is arguing with his wife or with God. The dances remain first-rate, particularly Teyve's dream sequence in which Motel the tailor is chosen as the husband for his oldest daughter. Marcia Lewis makes a wonderful Golde, shrewish yet ultimately sympathetic. There are some sharp cameos particularly Ruth Jaroslow as the busybody matchmaker, Mark Zeller as the butcher Lazar Wolf and Tia Riebling as the sweet-voiced Hodel. Boris Aronson's original designs, with their echoes of Marc Chagall paintings, remain as evocative as ever, particularly Teyve's house which spins around the large stage and opens gracefully to reveal its homespun interior to the audience. At one of the final preview performances, the audience was swept up into the show as soon as the curtain rose. Many of them began humming along with the score. They knew what to expect, and this revival delivers it. The one surprise may be that this ``Fiddler on the Roof'' turns out to be as good as they remember the musical to be.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Animal Trainer Bids Goodbye To The Big Top
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: For two years, animal trainer Gunther Gebel-Williams has been bidding farewell in what has arguably been one of the longest exits in entertainment history. But his honest-to-gosh last goodbye under the Big Top scared him more than the beasts whose many scars he carries. ``Don't cry. Don't make it hard on me,'' the star of Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus said to his son, Mark, in the grand finale of Sunday's show. His daughter, Tina, who also performs in the circus, hugged him and handed him a box of tissues as the audience at the Civic Arena gave him a standing ovation. The circus, not known for understatement, unfurled banners shouting, ``Gunther,'' and life-size posters of the man humbly billed as the ``Golden Gladiator,'' ``Teutonic Tiger Trainer,'' ``Caesar of the Circus'' and ``Lord of the Rings.'' Eighteen elephants reared back and formed a line, each animal with its front legs on another's back. The trainer, who came from Germany 22 years ago, explained recently why he's leaving the Big Top at age 56: ``Everybody asks me, `Why now?' I want to step down when I am really good. I don't want to be like Ali, Sugar Ray Leonard, `Another fight, another fight.' ... Every show is always a risk for me. How long can you take that? There are always young tigers.'' On Sunday, Gebel-Williams thanked fellow performers, circus owner Kenneth Feld, the audience and other circus owners from around the world who came to pay tribute. The crowd sang ``Auld Lang Syne,'' the traditional conclusion of the circus' two-year tour, as Gebel-Williams skipped off waving goodbye. In his 21 years with Ringling Bros., Gebel-Williams has performed 11,697 shows before an estimated 100 million people. He appeared in Madison Square Garden more times than Frank Sinatra, Jack Dempsey or any other entertainer and has a plaque to prove it. Son Mark, 20, will carry on the act - with African and Indian elephants, white Lippizaner horses, zebras and camels - but without Gebel-Williams' tigers. The trainer is so devoted to the tigers - and so fearful that they won't transfer their devotion to his son - that they will retire with him to his winter home in Venice, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Opposition Lifts Legislative Boycott
DOC.TEXT: The top opposition party is ending its four-month-old boycott of parliament, the party leader announced Monday. Kim Dae-jung, head of the largest opposition Party for Peace and Democracy, said the party's 70 national legislators would take their seats in the National Assembly later in the day. The other opposition party in parliament, the splinter Democratic Party, said members had not decided whether to follow suit. That party has eight legislators. ``There are numerous tasks and issues waiting to be resolved,'' Kim told a news conference. He said rival political leaders had reached agreement on ending the boycott, including a key pledge to hold local elections in 1991. ``If the regime fails to fulfill its promise on all the issues affecting people's lives, it should be prepared to resign,'' Kim said. The 78 opposition members of the 299-member parliament resigned en masse in July, charging President Roh Tae-woo's governing Democratic Liberal Party with railroading bills and reneging on democratic reform. The boycott was effectively ended over the weekend after rival political leaders reached agreement on holding the local elections. South Korea has not had local elections since they were abolished by an authoritarian regime 30 years ago. The opposition had also demanded the cancellation of governing party plans to change South Korea's system of government from presidential to parliamentary. Critics said it was a ploy by the governing party to prolong control of power. That matter was settled earlier this month after a rival faction within the governing party revolted against the president and announced its objection to a change in the system of government. Roh backed down and promised not to push for the change.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Record Biggest Drop Since Gulf Crisis Began
DOC.TEXT: The average price of gasoline fell almost a penny a gallon over the past two weeks - the biggest drop nationwide since the Persian Gulf crisis began - according to a survey released Sunday. Prices dropped for all grades except leaded regular at full service pumps, the Lundberg Survey of 13,500 stations found. The survey compared prices Nov. 16 with those of Nov. 2, when the survey was last conducted. The national average for all grades of gasoline was 145.98 cents, a drop of about .94 cent a gallon since Nov. 2. Trilby Lundberg, who directs the survey, attributed the drop to recent declines in wholesale prices. The survey found average prices at self-service pumps were 135.10 cents for regular unleaded, 151.19 cents for premium unleaded and 131.61 cents for regular leaded. Averages at full-service stations were 157.76 cents for regular unleaded, 171.41 cents for premium unleaded and 154.90 cents for regular leaded. Lundberg said that while the Nov. 2 survey showed drops in some parts of the nation, the latest survey reflected drops nationwide. It was the first significant drop in price since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Test Developed for `Yuppie Flu,' Researcher Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 12-13, `In any case...,' to ADD name of cell checked for in blood test. Pick up 14th graf pvs, `Levy said...
DOC.TEXT: A blood test has been devised to help doctors diagnose chronic fatigue syndrome, a flu-like illness some have dubbed ``yuppie flu,'' a scientist said Sunday. Dr. Jay Levy of San Francisco announced the development at a national conference on the disease here. He predicted the mysterious illness will be the ``disease of the '90s'' as the public and the medical community become more aware of it. ``It takes about decade before the public wakes up and realizes that this is not going to go away,'' Levy said. The weekend conference, titled ``Unraveling the Mystery,'' drew 400 people including researchers and people afflicted with the ailment. Chronic fatigue syndrome is characterized by fatigue, exhaustion, joint and muscle aches, and an array of other problems that persist for more than six months, and often for years. Tens of thousands of Americans believe they have chronic fatigue syndrome, although the extent of it is uncertain. Some researchers believe the disease may be centuries old and it's just been misdiagnosed all this time. Because it has been widely reported among well-educated women in their 30s and 40s, the syndrome was dubbed ``yuppie flu.'' An effort to discover how widespread it is, an inter-agency coordinating commmittee has been formed, said Dr. Walter Gunn, a chronic fatigue syndrome researcher at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. Levy, an AIDS researcher at the University of California at San Francisco, led a group that developed a blood test for the disease. Levy said his team was unable to find one virus that caused the illness. Some research has linked the syndrome to a retrovirus, one of the family of viruses that causes AIDS. ``Because of the immune profile of these patients, we believe there has been an infection by some agent, though this agent may no longer be in the body,'' Levy said. ``Or it may be hidden. It cannot as yet be identified.'' In any case, he said, the immune system of chronic fatigue patients is activated for months or years, creating high levels of a particular white blood cell, caled the CD8+ cytotoxic T cell. The persistence of the white blood cell causes symptoms of a viral infection, Levy said. The CD8+ cytotoxic cells appear to be the major cell type activated in the disease - a signature unique to chronic fatigue syndrome, Levy said. So the blood test checks for high levels of those cells. ``This is a way to distinguish those with fatigue alone from those with an immune reaction that causes chronic fatigue,'' he said. Levy said the level of the white blood cells along with an examination of the patient's medical history could determine whether a patient is suffering from the syndrome. Levy and other researchers suggested the syndrome be renamed ``chronic immune activation syndrome'' to reflect their findings.

DOC.HEAD: Legalized Gambling Brings Land Rush to 3 Colorado Mining Towns
DOC.TEXT: Gamblers whose game of choice is real estate won big in this old mining town by betting correctly that state voters would approve a referendum to allow limited gambling here. Colorado voters on Nov. 6 allowed limited-stakes gambling for this town below Pikes Peak as well as in Central City and Black Creek. Before Election Day more than 50 properties changed hands in Cripple Creek. The prices paid were up to 10 times their previous price, the Teller County assessor's office said. At least 27 lots in the town's historic district - its future gambling district, sold for nearly $1.9 million, the Rocky Mountain News reported Sunday. The winner so far in that gamble seems to be Norbert Larsen, a Cripple Creek construction worker. Larsen bought 10 lots in the historic district for $40,000 in July. He sold them Oct. 26 to the Seravalli family of Daytona Beach, Fla., for $200,000, records show. ``(If) you don't gamble, you don't win,'' Larsen said. ``It's all gambling. Some people are going to make their money gambling on land, some on running a business, some playing poker... I won.'' The Seravallis snapped up at least 20 of the 27 lots in the historic district. John Seravalli Sr. and his twin sons, John Jr. and Joseph, put up $1.2 million for the prime properties, the paper said. Central City and Black Hawk are two former mining towns about 25 miles west of Denver. The referendum makes it legal in the three towns to make wagers up to $5 on such games as blackjack and poker. Some property owners are still holding out for an irresistible offer. Vern ``Terp'' Terpening, who has owned Terp's Leather Goods in Central City for more than 40 years, wants $4.5 million for his 12,000 square feet on Main Street, plus two houses and property in town. The propety was assessed at $1.7 million two years ago. ``I've heard all these stories about the outrageous amounts of money I've been offered, and nobody's sorrier than me they're not true,'' Terpening said. ``I'd love to hear some outrageous offers.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks Support for Gulf Policy, Asks Germany to Take More Active Role
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Baker-Shevardnadze meeting, subs 9th graf pvs: Bush is ....; with new grafs 9-13; picks up 10th graf pvs: White House ....; cuts last 3 grafs to tighten.
DOC.TEXT:
President Bush on Sunday began a series of meetings with allied leaders aimed at solidifying support for his Persian Gulf policies. He urged German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to take a more active role in confronting Iraq's ``challenges to peace and freedom.'' During a rain-drenched half day in Germany, Kohl cautioned Bush against pursuing a military solution before exhausting all avenues of negotiation. Bush said he, too, would like to see a peaceful solution to the crisis. The president then traveled to Paris for a 34-nation summit of North American and European nations. It was the third stop on an eight-day trip highlighted by the signing Monday of a conventional forces treaty with the Soviet Union and Thanksgiving dinner with U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. French President Francois Mitterrand hosted Bush for Sunday dinner and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait was high on the agenda. Mitterrand, like Kohl is stressing a non-ilitary outcome to the Persian Gulf crisis. During the 45-minute dinner, Bush and Mitterrand agreed ``that it is necessary to pursue and strengthen the action taken in the framework of the U.N. Security Council,'' Mitterrand spokesman Hubert Vedrine said. In Rome, meanwhile, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said ``new ideas'' have emerged to avert a war in the Persian Gulf. ``I am convinced that we will succeed in finding a way out of this deep crisis,'' he said. Gorbachev did not elaborate. Bush and Gorbachev planned to meet over breakfast Tuesday.
Bush is seeking to build support for a United Nations resolution authorizing military action to drive Iraq's Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. So far, the Soviets have not agreed. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze both declined to say after meeting Sunday if the Soviets would support the U.S.-proposed resolution on using force against Iraq. ``I cannot say that we have reached any decisions,'' Shevardnadze said. ``Tomorrow these discussions will continue at a presidential level. It's not so simple that we can just come out and announce something.'' Baker told reporters after the meeting to ``stay tuned'' and indicated an announcement could come Monday night. ``I have pointed out before the importance of maintaining to the extent we can a common approach and a common understanding with respect to this problem, and we're working on that,'' he said. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater shrugged off Iraq's announcement that it would release the hostages it has been holding, letting them go in groups between Christmas and March 25. ``We want all the hostages released,'' Fitzwater said in Paris. ``He (Saddam) does it all the time,'' the spokesman added, referring to other earlier gestures by Saddam in freeing foreigners. Fitzwater called the Saddam offer to release hostages after Christmas ``another cynical attempt by him to manipulate families' hopes and fears.'' He claimed the announcement appeared deliberately timed by Saddam as an effort to divert attention from Bush's planned Thanksgiving visit with troops in the Persian Gulf region. Baker said Saddam ``never should have taken them in the first place.'' Bush landed early Sunday evening at Orly Airport in Paris after visiting Kohl's home region of Oggersheim. Although Bush and Kohl sought to gloss over their differences, the two clearly came down on different sides of the issue of using force in the Persian Gulf. ``We're not ruling out any options, we're not ruling any options in,'' Bush said at a joint news conference with Kohl outside the German leader's home in this suburb of the industrial city of Ludwigshafen. But Kohl urged that ``everything be exhausted that there is to exhaust with negotiations.'' ``Whoever believes the problem can be solved militarily must consider not only the mission, but the end of the whole undertaking,'' Kohl said in a German radio interview aired shortly after Bush arrived. Bush, asked whether Kohl had delivered a similar warning during their private session, said: ``He made very clear he'd like to see a peaceful resolution to this question and so would I.'' ``Clearly, anybody that takes a look at the map and understands the realities of the world knows that this united Germany is and will be a tremendous force for peace and certainly for economic good in the world,'' Bush said. The Bush administration is looking to Germany to do more in the U.S.-led effort to drive Saddam from Kuwait. ``Just as a new Europe must look beyond its borders, so too must a united Germany take responsibility for leadership in our commonwealth of nations,'' Bush said in remarks prepared for a rain-shortened speech in the nearby 11th century cathedral town of Speyer. Although the driving rainstorm forced Bush to conclude his speech before he got to the part on the Persian Gulf, White House aides said the president stood by the remarks. Under pressure from the United States and other allies, Kohl has agreed to provide about $2 billion to assist front-line nations like Turkey and Jordan whose economies are battered by the economic boycott of Iraq. But, citing constitutional barriers, Germany has not sent any troops. Kohl, with national elections set for next week, may have been emphasizing his distaste for military action for domestic political purposes. But White House aides traveling with Bush privately voiced disappointment with his remarks, particularly coming during the president's visit. Rain dogged Bush throughout his six-hour visit to Germany, and he and Kohl were drenched as they stood on an uncovered raised wooden platform in the town square of Speyer. ``I see the rains are coming. So I will conclude, mercifully,'' Bush told his audience of 1,500, many of them huddled under umbrellas. The rain also prompted Kohl to cut short a joint news conference later in the day, but not before he put in a pitch for U.S. investment in what used to be East Germany. Despite their differences on the Persian Gulf, Bush praised Kohl as ``the man who united Germany.'' For his part, Kohl called Bush: ``One of the great architects of how Europe looks today.'' Earlier, as he flew to Germany from Prague, Czechoslovakia, Bush called Gorbachev's plan to dump his prime minister and give himself more power ``very interesting.'' Gorbachev on Saturday won tentative approval from Soviet lawmakers for a radical reorganization of the executive branch that will result in the dismissal of Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. ``We'll have a chance to talk to Mr. Gorbachev about all of that,'' Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One. Bush and Gorbachev will be among NATO and Warsaw Pact leaders signing a historic treaty slashing non-nuclear weapons in Europe. The two superpower leaders will also have a private breakfast on Tuesday. Bush said the arms treaty, which was initiated Sunday in Vienna by NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiatiors, ``seems to be overshadowed by what's happening in the Gulf. But it is a significant milestone.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Clear Rama Road, Nicaraguan Govt Says It Uncovered Plot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with vice president saying crackdown unjust; picks up 6th graf pvs, `About 200...
DOC.TEXT: Police and troops armed with machineguns on Sunday cleared sections of a strategic jungle road blocked for more than two weeks by protesters supporting the former Contra rebels. In a communique broadcast on radio and television late Saturday, President Violeta Chamorro said she had ordered the army to clear the Rama Road, which connects the eastern Caribbean coast with Managua and western Nicaragua. The statement, read by the information minister, Danilo Lacayo, indicated the government planned a crackdown on the protests that have left 24 people dead in the south and central regions of the country. In her communique, Mrs. Chamorro also accused former Contra leader Aristides Sanchez Herdocia of plotting the recent protests. She said he had orchestrated ``a broad plan against peace.'' Sanchez, who is under arrest in Managua, was a director of the U.S.-backed Nicaraguan Resistance that battled the former leftist Sandinista government for nine years. Vice President Virgilio Godoy, who is at odds with Mrs. Chamorro, met with 18 protesting mayors Sunday and said the government should be responding to the protesters with political answers, not arrests. ``The government should seek a way to satisfy the popular demands without showing it is humiliated or that it is losing authority,'' Godoy told the mayors. He called their actions ``a beautiful movement of civic, patriotic and peaceful protest with a popular base.'' He added that the government crackdown was intended ``to simplify and hide the responsibility of seeking solutions to the problems'' About 200 soldiers and police, backed by helicopters, on Sunday were tearing down barricades on the strategic 200-mile-long highway, where at least 13 barriers had been erected. Most of the troops were armed with automatic weapons and some rode in armored cars. The operation was peaceful, reporters at the scene said. In her statement, Mrs. Chamorro said: ``Faced with the existence of this dangerous plan and the need to reestablish free transportation along the Rama highway, the government ... ordered the forces of public order ... to normalize transit ... with the total clearing of all of the highway.'' The protesters want the government to fulfill promises of land and aid made to the former rebels. They also want members of the Sandinista opposition removed from key military and police posts. The Sandinistas still control security in Nicargua, despite losing a Feb. 25 election to Mrs. Chamorro, who took office in April. Rebels laid down their weapons in return for the promises of assistance. But by the government's own figures, barely 3,000 of the 20,000 rebels have received land. In her communique, Mrs. Chamorro said Sanchez had tried ``to manipulate the demands of the demobilized rebels with the intention of destabilizing the country.'' She did not elaborate on her allegations. On Saturday, a convoy of armored cars, police patrols and anti-riot vehicles rolled into Santo Tomas, about 75 miles east of Managua, to dismantle the barricades. They started work on Saturday afternoon. Rosa Jimenez de Farjardo, owner of a boarding house in Santo Tomas, said the convoy apparently met with no resistence. Anti-riot police used tear gas Thursday to dislodge a group of protesters on a stretch of road between Juigalpa and Santo Tomas. Town mayors in eastern and southeastern Nicaragua, backed by former Contra rebels, launched the protest movement Nov. 1 to demand that Mrs. Chamorro's administration break all ties with the leftist Sandinistas. They demand the firing of the Sandinista army chief, Gen. Humberto Ortega. They also have asked for the replacement of the minister of the presidency, Antoio Lacayo, and Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado. Protesters have also taken over churches and public buildings. Eighteen mayors have formed a Committee to Save Democracy to back the demands. As many as 75 out of Nicaragua's 147 mayors are said to be supporting them. They have been negotiating over the demands with the government. ``If we don't arrive at a satisfactory agreement, we will meet with all the mayors of the country to find a more energetic posture,'' said Armando Incer, a leader of the protest movement.

DOC.HEAD: Killer Scheduled for Electric Chair Monday Morning
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court refused Sunday to stop the execution of a man sentenced to die in the electric chair for killing a businessman for $5,000. The execution of Raymond Robert Clark was scheduled for 7:01 a.m. Monday ast Florida State Prison. The justices voted 8-1 against two separate emergency requests on Clark's behalf Sunday evening. The lone dissenter was Justice Thurgood Marshall, who opposes the death penalty in all circumstances. Defense attorney Billy Nolas said Clark had no other avenues of appeal left. Clark, 49, was convicted of the 1977 shooting death of a businessman. He and a teen-age accomplice abducted David Drake from a St. Petersburg bank parking lot, drove him to a secluded area and shot him twice in the head after Drake wrote them a $5,000 check, according to trial testimony. At the time, Clark was on parole after serving 10 years of a life sentence for killing a 14-year-old homosexual lover. Two weeks after Drake's disappearance, his family received a call demanding $10,000 ransom to return Drake unharmed, and police used a wiretap to trace the calls to Clark. On Saturday, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta granted Clark a reprieve until 7 a.m. Monday, but rejected his appeal, sending the case to the U.S. Supreme Court. The execution would be the 25th in Florida since the state resumed executions in 1979, and the 142nd nationwide since the U.S. Supreme court reinstated the death penalty in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Americans From Kuwait Arrive in Iraq

DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-chartered jetliner carrying 136 passengers, most of them Americans who had been living in Kuwait, arrived in London early Monday. Gatwick airport officials said the flight had 75 passengers from the United States, 10 New Zealanders, six Australians, two Danes, eight Germans, 12 Canadians, seven Irish, 12 Britons, two South Africans, one Polish woman and a French person. Many of those fleeing were the wives and children of Kuwaitis, saying they could no longer stand the horror the emirate had become since Iraq's invasion Aug. 2. ``For four months we have been in hiding,'' said an American woman who would not give her name. ``People are starving and they need food, but people who have food are frightened of giving it to them because they would be accused as collaborators.'' The woman, on the verge of tears, said her husband was still hiding in Kuwait and she did not know where he was. ``I stayed as long as I could,'' another woman from San Clemente, Calif., said before the plane left Baghdad. ``Kuwait went from the top to total destruction.'' The woman also refused to give her name. They had been among up to 2,000 Westerners believed still trapped in Kuwait. A spokesman at London's Gatwick Airport said the Americans would spend the night in London and travel to the United States later Monday. An earlier report from Baghdad when the plane left said there 133 passengers. The discrepancy was not explained. Diplomats said 123 of the passengers aboard the American-chartered Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 had been in Kuwait and arrived earlier in the day by plane. Also Sunday, about 40 Soviets left Iraq on board a separate Aeroflot flight. President Saddam Hussein refused to allow up to 20,000 Westerners to leave the country right after the invasion of Kuwait, but later relented and said women and children who wanted to leave could go. Many stayed behind with their husbands, whose travel has been generally restricted. The women leaving Sunday said their fear and the deteriorating situation in Kuwait drove them to leave. ``I was scared, I didn't believe this could happen to Kuwait. The country was a utopia,'' said the woman from San Clemente. A British woman named Julie who refused to give her last name said she gave up after spending more than 100 days there. ``You know, you lose hope. It's a simple as that. You just think, `What the hell am I staying here for? Why aren't they doing anything?''' The women interviewed said many Westerners were hoping for an attack, and some Iraqi troops appeared reluctant to face the Americans. Julie said one night during an unexpected blackout Iraqis ran into her building shouting, ``Hide us, hide us. The Americans are coming.'' ``They don't want to be there. They don't have a choice,'' she added. Said the San Clemente woman: ``I hate to say I want war to come to any country. But there were times I wished the Marines would come.'' Antoinette Rogers, a 21-year-old Irish woman married to a Kuwaiti, said she spent 45 minutes talking to a British friend in hiding before leaving. The friend said he was on the verge of cracking and turning himself over to the Iraqi authorities because he had already spent 115 days in hiding. ``Let us at least walk around,'' she quoted him as saying. ``Let me walk around half an hour every day. Just let me walk around. I'll do anything for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Promises To Free Hostages If `Atmosphere of Peace' Holds

DOC.TEXT: Iraq promised Sunday to release its remaining foreign hostages over three months starting on Christmas unless something ``mars the atmosphere of peace.'' President Bush said he hoped for peace but left open the prospect of war. There has been speculation that any military move to drive Iraq out of Kuwait would take place in the first several months of the year, and the Iraqi offer to free the hostages during that time appeared aimed at staving off such a strike. In a move meant to underscore U.S. readiness for war, American troops tried to stage a fullscale practice assault on a stretch of Saudi beach on Sunday. High winds and heavy seas, however, prevented hovercraft from making landings. In more limited maneuvers, troops came ashore by helicopter while U.S. and British warplanes provided simulated air cover. Thousands of foreigners were stranded by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, but hundreds have since been selectively released by the Baghdad government. The latest mass departure was Sunday, when 136 people flew into London from Iraq early Monday on a U.S.-arranged flight. Officials at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad said the passengers included 75 Americans, many of them wives and children of Kuwaiti nationals. ``I stayed as long as I could,'' said a woman from San Clemente, Calif., who would not give her name. ``Kuwait went from the top to total destruction.'' The official Iraqi News Agency said the decision to free the rest of the hostages came at a meeting presided over by Saddam. The foreign ``guests'' - as it calls the captives - would be allowed to leave beginning Dec. 25, it said. ``The last batch ... would leave the Iraqi territories on March 25 unless something would take place that mars the atmosphere of peace,'' said the news agency. The White House dismissed the move as another ploy by Saddam, and repeated its demand that all the captives be unconditionally freed. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, in Paris with the president, called the move a ``cynical attempt... to manipulate families' hopes and fears.'' Western governments in the past have denounced efforts by Saddam to use the captives as leverage in the gulf crisis. Bush, in Germany en route to Paris, conferred with Chancellor Helmut Kohl about the anti-Iraq alliance, which has assembled tens of thousands of troops in the gulf region. Bush called on the German leader to help ``keep the coalition together.'' Kohl, in a radio interview, underscored the need to do everything possible to resolve the gulf crisis diplomatically before resorting to force. Although Bush has spoken in strong terms about the possibility of a military strike, he played down any differences of opinion. ``We're not ruling out any options, we're not ruling any options in,'' he said. Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev were to join leaders of 20 other nations in Paris signing a conventional forces treaty that reduces troop and arms levels in Europe. From Paris, Bush was flying to the Mideast, and planned to spend Thanksgiving with U.S. soldiers in the gulf region. Gorbachev, who met with Pope John Paul II at the Vatican before leaving for Paris, said he believes there is a peaceful way out of the gulf crisis. ``I am convinced that we will succeed in finding a way out of this deep crisis,'' Gorbachev said, speaking in Russian that was translated into Italian. The Vatican said the pontiff, in the meeting with Gorbachev, expressed hopes that war could be avoided. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, meanwhile, conferred with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas about a potential U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq. Dumas repeated the French position that the U.N. economic embargo is the best way to force Iraq to relinquish Kuwait. Baker said such views did not mean the coalition was divided. ``Let me suggest to you that I'm not aware of any countries, going back to the very beginning of this crisis, who have taken the position under any and all circumstances that the option of force should be ruled out,'' Baker told reporters. The U.S. amphibious landing exercise that was canceled Sunday was to have been the centerpiece of the six-day Imminent Thunder maneuvers. But if it had been war instead of practice, the amphibious landing would have gone ahead despite high winds and heavy seas, U.S. military officials said. One of the landing craft was launched from the USS Gunston Hall, but it wallowed in seas of up to 10 feet. The exercise was rescheduled for Monday. The maneuvers were held about 25 miles off the Saudi coast, 100 miles south of the Kuwaiti border. Iraq had denounced the exercises as ``provocative'' after reports they would be held as close as 10 miles from Kuwait. In other developments: -The U.S. military on Sunday announced the death of the 47th U.S. soldier in Operation Desert Shield. Officials said the soldier, whose name was not released pending notification of kin, was killed late Saturday when a truck he was riding in crashed in eastern Saudi Arabia. -Two brothers and a sister of a U.S. hostage arrived in Jordan Sunday en route to Baghdad. The State Department had urged relatives of hostages not to accept an Iraqi invitation to visit, but William Stevenson of Panama City, Fla., whose brother John is a captive, told reporters at the Amman airport: ``This is strictly a family business.''

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Despite Business Efforts, Customers are Widely Unhappy with Service
DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 p.m. EST, Sunday.
DOC.TEXT: Whether it's handling complaints from irate shoppers or pampering hotel guests, customer service has become a top priority for most American executives, according to a poll released Sunday. About half the customers have noticed, according to the poll. The poll, commissioned by John Hancock Financial Services and conducted by Louis Harris and Associates Inc., surveyed both consumers and senior executives from service-oriented businesses, such as retailers, utilities and financial services companies. The poll found the vast majority of executives placed a premium on quality customer service, but 50 percent of the consumers said service is improving. That number was the highest it has been in the 19 years the Harris group has surveyed attitudes on service. Forty-five percent of the customers polled, however, still feel quality is declining. Moreover, 51 percent reported declining personal attention from service providers, and 60 percent perceived declining value for the money they spend. ``There is a big gap there,'' said Stephen L. Brown, president of Hancock. ``You have to assume the customer is always right in this case.'' The poll also asked the public to rank various service industries on how well they respond to customer complaints. From top to bottom they were: retailers; leisure-entertainment-hospitality; banks; telecommunications; utilities; health care; other financial institutions; and insurance companies. Brown, whose company specializes in insurance, said he was not surprised by the low ranking of his industry. Insurance is a ``complex product,'' he said. ``It lends itself to misunderstanding. It's difficult to deliver the service people expect.'' Four out of five senior executives said quality service can help increase their market share and profitability and would encourage customers to buy other products and services from their companies. Also, 95 percent of the executives have made quality service an ``explicit part of their business plan,'' and 91 percent said they have taken steps to monitor quality service and customer satisfaction. Some executives have been able to drive this message down to every level of their organizations, but ``I don't think it's been done at a lot of companies,'' Brown said. The survey questioned 500 executives and 1,250 consumers around the country in July and August. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Says Justice Not Giving Priority To S&L Fraud Probes
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Deprtment has not given the investigation and prosecution of fraud in the multibillion dollar savings and loan scandal the priority the public demands, a House panel concluded in a report released Sunday. The Government Operations subcommittee on commerce, consumer and monetary affairs said the department repeatedly has misled Congress over the past two years about funding needed to catch and jail savings and loan crooks. In addition, the report said, the department has failed to address issues that have hampered investigation and prosecution of savings and loan fraud, such as the FBI's lack of document subpoena authority and inadequate pay for FBI agents and prosecutors. ``The Justice Department's rhetoric concerning its priorities has not matched its willingness to address a number of issues ... which continue to adversely affect the U.S. government's ability to apply the criminal justice system to culpable individuals,'' Rep. Doug Barnard, D-Ga., chairman of the subcommittee, said in a statement. ``I have great difficulty in accepting that a person who commits substantial fraud against a S&L or bank may completely escape investigation and prosecution if that person committed the offense in most areas of the United States that did not receive enough additional resources,'' he said. Doug Tillett, a spokesman for the Justice Department, said he could not comment on the report until the department has a chance to review it. But he noted that in the past 13 months, 519 individuals have been charged in major savings and loan fraud cases - those involving losses of $100,000 or more - and 355 have been convicted. Congress authorized $75 million in the 1989 savings and loan bailout legislation to beef up prosecution of individuals who looted thrift institutions, but the administration sought and Congress appropriated only $50 million for fiscal 1990. In its fiscal 1991 budget, the administration initially sought to increase that allocation only by $1.8 million. But after complaints from Congress, President Bush announced last June he wanted to double the $50 million in fiscal 1991. Congress ultimately appropriated $176 million to the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service for S&L fraud investigation and prosecution during the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. But even with the extra money, according to Barnard's subcommittee, the FBI still is $8 million short of what it needs to hire the agents and support staff its division offices requested in 1989 for S&L fraud enforcement, and $26 million short of what it needs to deal with a backlog of more than 21,000 inactive S&L cases. ``These past failures to ask for sufficient funds have resulted in more delays, more stale cases and many cases which may not be brought because of statute of limitations problems or fading memories,'' the report said. The House subcommittee recommended that federal bank regulatory agencies make 140 to 180 examiners and attorneys available within the next four months to help the FBI and federal prosecutors eliminate the backlog of financial fraud cases. The panel also recommended that Congress upgrade the pay of federal law enforcement agents and prosecutors to reduce the rapid personnel turnover that is ``seriously delaying and negatively impacting'' investigation and prosecution of financial fraud, especially in New York and California. In another area, the subcommittee said Congress should grant the FBI the authority to subpoena documents related to savings and loan fraud. Currently, federal prosecutors must impanel a grand jury to issue a subpoena during an ongoing investigation each time the FBI requires documents. While the FBI already has document subpoena authority in drug cases and has been seeking similar authority in S&L fraud cases since 1988, the report said opposition from key federal prosecutors apparently has kept the Justice Department from seeking the appropriate legislation.
